questions.text: Understanding of the mechanics of the muscles surrounding the shoulder joint also referred to as the "rotator cuff muscles," have grown. exponentially. One of the rotator cuff muscles, often regarded as the "lost rotator cuff muscles," has, however, had its function neglected or given less significance. Which of the four muscles most accurately fits the bill for this description?
questions.solution:
The Subscapularis, one of the major and most powerful muscles of the rotator cuff, is often overlooked in the clinical literature, even though it is essential to glenohumeral stability and dynamics. It has been deemed that the subscapularis tendon is the "forgotten tendon" due to its separate insertion at lesser tubercle of humerus as compared to rest of the 3 muscles which get inserted at greater tubercle. 

The rotator cuff muscles are :
1. Subscapularis
2. Supraspinatus
3. Infraspinatus
4. Teres Minor ( and not major )



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 813,785.e1

questions.text: Pick the one out of the following structures which is absent from the floor of third ventricle ?
questions.solution:
The third Cranial nerve (Oculomotor) does not form the floor of the third ventricle although it lies in close relation to the floor. Floor of Third Ventricle Formed by - Optic Chiasma Infundibular recess Tuber cinerium Mammillary bodies Posterior perforated substance Tegmentum of the midbrain



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 409

questions.text: Pick the option that does not contribute to the formation of the facial recess in human beings.
questions.solution:
The facial recess, or posterior sinus, is a depression found on the posterior wall next to the pyramid. It is bordered Medially by the vertical portion of the VIIth nerve Laterally by the chorda tympani, and Above by the fossa incudis. When it comes to surgeries, the facial recess is an important area, as it provides a direct route into the middle ear while preserving the posterior canal wall.



Reference-: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 8th Edition Page no 6-9

questions.text: The urethra's elevation, known as the urethral crest, is caused by:
questions.solution:
Urethral crest is an elevation seen in the urethra due to trigonal muscles. 

In males, the urethral crest is known as the crista urethralis masculinae and is a longitudinal fold on the posterior wall of the urethra extending from the uvula of the bladder through the prostatic urethra. It contains muscular and erectile tissue. When distended, it may serve to prevent the passage of the semen backward into the bladder.

In females, it is known as the crista urethralis femininae, and is a conspicuous longitudinal fold of mucosa on the posterior wall of the urethra.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1278

questions.text: Pick the option that does not contribute to the formation of anorectal ring in human beings?
questions.solution: Anorectal Ring is a muscular ring present at the anorectal junction. It is formed by the fusion of the Puborectalis, the uppermost fibers of the external sphincter, and the internal sphincter. Thus Anococcygeal raphe does not contribute to its formation.

questions.text: Which of these is not a part of the inferior wall of orbit?
questions.solution:
The inferior wall of the orbit is formed by the following bones -
  • Zygomatic
  • Maxillary
  • Palatine
Ethmoid bone forms the boundary of the medial wall.




 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 769

questions.text: Which of the following nerves, when damaged, affects lacrimation?
questions.solution: The greater petrosal nerve is a branch of the facial nerve, which arises from the geniculate ganglion, and ultimately supplies the lacrimal gland along with mucosal glands of nose, palate, and pharynx. Damage to it will deprive the lacrimal gland from its secretomotor fibers and this would lead to the absence of tears, along with other complications.

questions.text: The needle is inserted through all of the following structures during fluid draining from the pleural cavity, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Structures pierced by the Needle during Pleural Tapping in the Mid-Axillary Line - 

1. Skin

2. Superficial fascia 

3. Muscles(Intercostal)

4. Endothoracic fascia 

5. Parietal pleura

Thus, the pulmonary pleura/visceral pleura is not pierced.



Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557710/

questions.text: Pick the only complete cartilage ring in the respiratory tree.
questions.solution:
The cricoid cartilage is shaped like a ring and encircles the larynx below the thyroid cartilage. It is thicker/stronger in nature than thyroid cartilage. Also, it is the only complete cartilage ring.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 719

questions.text: Where is vaginal epithelium is derived from?
questions.solution:
The entire vaginal epithelium ( Upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd ) is derived from the endoderm of the urogenital sinus.



Reference-: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2943051/

questions.text: Which of these inhibits the release of synaptic vesicle from the presynaptic terminal?
questions.solution:
Release of the synaptic vesicle from the presynaptic terminal is inhibited by prevention of calcium influx.

When calcium ions (Ca2+) enter the presynaptic terminal through voltage-gated calcium channels, they bind to several proteins involved in a synaptic vesicle (SV) exocytosis such as SNARE proteins and synaptotagmins.

This triggers a conformational change in the proteins, resulting in the release of neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft.


If the calcium ions are prevented from entering the presynaptic terminal, the proteins involved will not undergo their conformational changes and exocytosis will be inhibited.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 104

choices.text: Immediately increase in venous return to heart
Decreased blood flow to the apex of lung

questions.text: Which of the following takes place when a standing person lies down?
questions.solution:
When a standing person lies down, there is an immediate increase in venous return. This happens due to the removal of the effect of gravity.

Other options:- 

  • Cerebral blood flow remains constant 
  • Blood flow to apex of lung increases 
  • Heart rate decreases
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 534

choices.text: Occurs after biphasic rise in basal body temperature
Occurs after the disappearance of cervical mucus thickening

questions.text: Pick the option that is correct with regards to the time of ovulation.
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options - only option (3) is correct. 

FSH and LH are both in charge of the follicular phase, thus controlling follicular ripening with a surge of LH leading to ovulation. These two hormones result in the maturation of the follicle.

Option 1 - Ovulation occurs after LH Surge (not before as given in option 1)

Option 2 - It is associated with a rise in basal body temperature (it doesn't occur after the rise)

Option 4 - Ovulation tends to occur during the period of highest cervical mucus thickening or one day after of this type of cervical secretion (but not after its disappearance)

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 392,393

questions.text: Pick the option that is correct regarding tracheobronchial luminal neuroendocrine cells.
questions.solution:
Neuroendocrine cells also known as APUD cells (Amine Precursor Uptake and Decarboxylase), can be found in the lungs and GIT (Gastrointestinal Tract). These cells contain serotonin, synthesize amines as well as polypeptides, and have been known to cause carcinoid tumors.



Reference:https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/apud-cell

choices.text: Passive diffusion of molecules along the concentration gradient
Active diffusion of molecules along the concentration gradient
Both passive and active diffusion of molecules along the concentration gradient

questions.text: What does Fick's law (Flick's law was given in the paper) deal with?
questions.solution:
Fick's Law deals with the Passive diffusion of molecules along the concentration gradient.

It states that particles of a substance in a solvent move randomly and are more likely to move from areas of high concentration to those of low concentration, resulting in a net movement of particles.

This reaction occurs over a period of time proportional to the square of the diffusion distance.

The speed of diffusion is dependent on the concentration gradient between two areas and the area of contact




Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 6

questions.text: What is embryonal hemoglobin mainly composed of?
questions.solution:
Embryonic hemoglobin is formed by Epsilon and zeta. 1. Fetal Hemoglobin(HbF): made up of two alpha and two gamma chains 2. Adult Hemoglobin (HbA): made up of two alpha and two beta chains 3. Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2): made up of two alpha and two delta chains




Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 548,549

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the Kluver-Bucy syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Visual agnosia, hypersexuality, hyperorality and hypermetamorphosis are characteristics of Kluver-Bucy syndrome.
  • However, intractable seizures are not seen in this. 
  • Kluver-Bucy Syndrome (KBS) is a rare neurological disorder caused by damage to the medial temporal lobes of the brain.
  • The condition is characterized by hypersexuality, oral behaviors such as hyperoralism and pica, and an overall lack of fear.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 14, 518.

choices.text: Damage to both respiratory apparatus and respiratory centre

questions.text: Following an accident, a motorcyclist experiences elevated arterial pCO2. on ABG. Possible reasons include:
questions.solution:
Elevated arterial pCO2 points towards Respiratory acidosis.

In this case of RTA(road traffic accident)-Respiratory acidosis can be caused by depression of the respiratory center due to injury and the same accident would be causing damage to the respiratory apparatus(that is lungs/ribs/chest wall) which also would be contributing to respiratory acidosis and high arterial pCO2.


Hence, option (3) is correct. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 646,647

questions.text: Inorganic "metals" are integrated into the body and made a component of biological structures through a process called biomineralization. An illustration of biomineralization can be found in:
questions.solution:
Biomineralization is the process by which living organisms produce minerals, often to harden or stiffen existing tissues. Such tissues are called mineralized tissues.

Mollusc shell is an example of this process of Biomineralization.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 93.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures should be used to restore a cell membrane that has been damaged by the insertion of a microneedle?
questions.solution:
Repair of a cell membrane damaged by insertion of microneedle shall occur by resealing by lipid bilayer (Note: Macropuncture is repaired by Ca2+ ion mediated vesicle exocytosis

Reference:https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/lipid-bilayer

questions.text: Which is the most common metabolite of progesterone excreted in urine?
questions.solution:
Most common end product of progesterone metabolism found in urine is Pregnanediol

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 401

questions.text: Which of the following is unable to make use of Ketone bodies?
questions.solution:
RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria.

The heart can make use of fatty acids in any state whereas the brain uses it only during periods of starvation.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 655.

questions.text: Pick the one known as "suicidal enzyme" from the given options.
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options - Cyclooxygenase is an enzyme that has the ability to deactivate itself, a process known as suicidal inhibition.

This ability is what allows it to regulate the production of prostaglandins by switching off its activity.

Another example of suicidal inhibition is Xanthine oxidase, which converts a substrate into a metabolite that is a far more powerful inhibitor of itself.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 224.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to pediatric OPD with hepatospleenomegaly. Large cells that resemble crumpled paper were seen on bone marrow examination. In these cells, which of the following must have accumulated?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Gaucher's disease, caused by the deposition of Glucocerebrosides due to deficiency of beta- glucocerebrosidase. 

The cerebrocide-laden cells are large and have eccentric nuclei.

The cytoplasm appears like crumpled silk or tissue paper (Gaucher's Cells).

With the electron microscope, the fibrillary cytoplasm can be resolved as elongated, distended lysosomes containing the stored lipid in stacks of bilayers.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 245.

questions.text: Pick the enzyme that catalyses the irreversible steps of glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Reactions catalyzed by hexokinase (glucokinase), phosphofructokinase, and pyruvate kinase, are the three major sites of regulation of glycolysis as other reactions of glycolysis are reversible.

The reactions catalyzed by these three enzymes are markedly exergonic and are considered to be physiologically irreversible.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 165.

choices.text: Oxaloacetate, required for gluconeogenesis, is present in excess.

questions.text: Ketosis was discovered after an examination of a patient who had Von gierke disease. Which of the following is not correct regarding the described condition?
questions.solution:
Von Gierke's disease is a type 1 glycogen storage disorder which occurs due to deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatse.

Due to deficiency of this enzyme, liver is unable to release glucose into bloodstream during fasting. Therefore, in order to produce glucose, body shifts to gluconeogenesis but fails again due to deficiency of the enzyme.

Excess glucose-6-phosphate, therefore, enters HMP pathway to form purines and this in turn results in hyperuricemia.

Glucose-6-phopshate is broken down to acetyl co-A for utilization in TCA cycle but this process does not occur due to depletion of oxaloacetate( OAA decreases and no rise as it gets diverted to gluconeogenesis). It is therefore, diverted towards fatty acid and ketone body synthesis causing hypertriglyceridemia and ketosis.

OAA is in excess for gluconeogenesis but not for ketosis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: How does one identify the exact location of a genetic loci is?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options - Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) can help in identifying the exact location of genetic loci.

Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that is used to detect and locate the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It uses fluorescent probes that attach to very specific regions of DNA, allowing for the visualization of the exact location or loci of specific genes on a chromosome.

FISH can be used to detect genetic rearrangements associated with diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and even the presence of specific genes in a sample. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: Pick the enzyme that does not participate in oxidation- reduction reactions?
questions.solution:
Enzymes involved in oxidation-reduction reactions are called oxidoreductases.

Enzymes are classified into six classes.

1. Oxidoreductases - Catalyze oxidations and reductions.
2. Transferases- Catalyze the transfer of moieties such as glycosyl,methyl,or phosphoryl.
3. Hydrolases- Catalyze the hydroytic cleavage of C-C,C-N and other covalent bonds.
4. Lyases-  Catalyze cleavage of C-C,C-O,C-N and other covalent bonds by atom elimination,generating double bonds.
5. Isomerases-  Catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
6. Ligases-Catalyze the joining together(ligation) of two molecules in reaction coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP.

Hydrolases are not involved in oxidation-reduction reactions and do not belong to the family of oxidoreductases.
Hydrolases are a class of enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of various chemical bonds, such as ester, peptide, and glycosidic bonds, by breaking them down with the addition of water. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 57.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in the orbit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B cell
 
  • Orbital lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that originates in the conjunctiva, lacrimal gland, soft tissues of the eyelid, or extraocular muscles. It is most commonly extraconal in location.
  • The majority of non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas of the orbit are extra nodal marginal-zone B-cell lymphomas of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue type.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 612.

choices.text: Anemic hemoglobin has greater oxygen carrying capacity per unit gram of hemoglobin
A critical concentration of reduced hemoglobin is required
Due to decreased oxygen-carrying capacity of blood
Blood flow through the skin is decreased in anemia

questions.text: In cases of severe anaemia, cyanosis does not manifest because
questions.solution:
Cyanosis is a dusky blue discoloration of the skin caused by blood in the capillaries containing reduced hemoglobin when its concentration exceeds >5 g/dL in blood. Anemic individuals already have severely depleted hemoglobin levels (sometimes lower than 5g/dL) and hence, this critical concentration of reduced hemoglobin is not reached to manifest cyanosis.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 632

choices.text: ESR is raised because of increased RBC aggregate
ESR is raised due to decreased RBC size

questions.text: ESR testing is very important in the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Which statement regarding ESR in TB is accurate?
questions.solution:
The ESR is a non-specific test to detect inflammation in the body.
During inflammation positive phase reactants like fibrinogen is increased.
It is based on the phenomenon of fibrinogen binding to red cells and causing them to form stacks (rouleaux), which sediment faster at unit gravity than individual cells( hence, ESR being higher or raised).
This is used to measure the presence of inflammation and is a useful indicator of tissue damage or disease in the body.
In TB - there would be inflammation causing a higher ESR.



Reference-: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7518781/

questions.text: When does neurocysticercosis become nonedematous?
questions.solution:
There are four main stages of neurocysticercosis (also known as Escobar's pathological stages):

 1.Vesicular: viable parasite with intact membrane and therefore no host reaction. 

 2.Colloidal vesicular: parasite dies within 4-5 years untreated, or earlier with treatment and the cyst fluid becomes turbid. As the membrane
                                     becomes leaky edema surrounds the cyst. This is the most symptomatic stage.

3.Granular nodular: edema decreases as the cyst retract further
4.Nodular calcified: end-stage quiescent calcified cyst remnant; no edema.

Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1493.

questions.text: For which of these is real time polymerase chain reaction done?
questions.solution:
A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time), not at its end, as in conventional PCR. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: What does the division of a chromosome perpendicular to the normal axis of division lead to?
questions.solution:
Isochromosomes show loss of one arm with duplication of other due to perpendicular rather than horizonta separation of chromosomes. 

Most common isochromosome encountered is 2 q arms of X chromosome which is seen in ~ 15% patients of Turner's syndrome. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Inflammation

Apoptosis is a process of cells undergoing programmed cell death whereby unwanted cells are removed by the activation of specific genetic pathways.

Characteristic features of apoptosis include all, but it does not involve inflammation. 
 
* Characteristic features of apoptosis include-

  • Condensation of chromatin
  • Fragmentation of DNA,
  • Shrinkage of the Cell membrane (it stays intact)
  • Phagocytic recognition and removal
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 42.

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T-cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What role does Major Histocompatibility complex-1 and complex-2 play?
questions.solution:
MHC proteins - Their role is in the recognition and presentation of antigens to the immune system. MHC class I (MHC1) - Present on all nucleated cells and platelets - They are responsible for presenting HIV, EBV, and CMV viruses, among others, to our immune system. MHC class II (MHC2) - Present on Antigen-presenting cells - are responsible for presenting pollen, foods, and other foreign proteins to the immune system.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 141.

questions.text: Why is insulin resistance is seen in liver disease?
questions.solution:
Insulin resistance in liver disease is primarily associated with 3. Hepatocyte dysfunction. Hepatocyte dysfunction can impair insulin signaling pathways, leading to decreased glucose uptake and altered glucose production, contributing to insulin resistance. While hepatic steatosis (fatty liver) can also play a role, it is the dysfunction of liver cells that is a key factor in the development of insulin resistance.

 

Reference:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 2578

questions.text: Pick the trial that can be performed to determine the maximal tolerated dose of a drug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phase I trial

Phase I which includes Human Pharmacology and safety testing is performed to determine the maximum tolerated dose of a drug.
* Later stages include -
  • Phase II: Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging
  • Phase III: Therapeutic confirmation and comparison
  • Phase IV: Post-marketing surveillance and studies.
In Phase I Clinical trial - Subjects (mostly healthy volunteers, sometimes patients) are exposed to the drug one by one, starting with the lowest estimated dose and increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 90.

choices.text: Both efficacy and non-efficacy of the drug
Either efficacy and non-efficacy of the drug

questions.text: The 95% confidence interval is employed in clinical trials to look for the following things when evaluating a newly produced drug's effectiveness in contrast to placebo:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Efficacy of the drug

  • Confidence intervals are estimates that provide a lower and upper threshold to the estimate of the magnitude of effect.
  • By convention, 95% confidence intervals are most typically reported.
  • These intervals represent the range in which we can, with 95% confidence, assume the treatment effect to fall within.
  • Confidence interval in a drug trial is used to test its clinical efficacy, it would suggest to what amount the effect observed can be contributed to the drug and is not by chance.
  • In contrast, if the clinical merits of a treatment appear different when considering the possibility of the lower versus the upper confidence intervals, one may be more cautious about the expected benefits to be anticipated with treatment.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 84.

choices.text: Should be present in the same tissue as the primary target

questions.text: One of the many mechanisms of adverse events of a drug is its increased binding to secondary targets, usually proteins. With respect to the primary target, the secondary target:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Should have similar binding sites 
 
  • One of the many mechanisms of adverse events is its increased binding to secondary targets, usually proteins. With respect to primary target, the secondary target should have similar binding sites. 
  • Many drugs, such as aspirin, barbiturates, phenytoin, sulfonamides, valproic acid, and warfarin, are highly protein bound in the plasma, and it is the free (unbound) drug that produces the clinical effects.
  • These drugs may have enhanced toxicity in overdose if protein-binding sites become saturated in physiological states that lead to hypoalbuminemia, or when displaced from plasma proteins by other drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 94.

questions.text: All of the following medications metabolism is inhibited by Ritonavir with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Phenytoin 
 
  • All protease inhibitors inhibit the metabolism of drugs by CYP3A4 - Hence, Ritonavir Inhibits the metabolism of Amiodarone, Cisapride, and Midazolam, but not Phenytoin.
  • This is because majority (95%) of phenytoin is metabolized principally in the hepatic endoplasmic reticulum by CYP2C9/10. 
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1255.

questions.text: Pick the injection that is available for subcutaneous administration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Terbutaline 
 
  • Amongst the given options - option (2) can be given subcutaneously. 
  • Subcutaneous injections of Terbutaline (Beta 2 adrenergic agonist) are utilized in patients who have acute asthma flare-ups and cannot cooperate with nebulized therapy with beta 2 agonists.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 243.

questions.text: Which receptor mediates dysphoria caused by opiates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) kappa

Kappa receptors for opioids cause dysphoria.

* [Extra Edge]: Functions of Opioid Receptor



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 507.

questions.text: Which part of the nephron is affected by Vasopressin antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Medullary collecting duct
 
  • Vasopressin antagonists act on Medullary collecting duct of nephron.
  • By inhibiting vasopressin receptors, they decrease binding of vasopressin to its target site thereby decreasing adenylyl cyclase activity and reduced intracellular cAMP. Decreased cAMP prevents the fusion of aquaporin 2 containing vesicles with plasma membrane, leading to increased urinary water excretion and decrease in urine osmolality.
  • Examples are- Conivaptan (acts on V1 and V2 receptors and given intravenously) and tolvaptan (V2 selective given orally)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: Pick the option that is correct regarding orphan drugs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Drugs used for rare diseases 
 
  • Orphan drug is a medication used to treat, prevent, or diagnose an orphan disease.
  • An orphan disease is a rare disease or condition that affects fewer than 200,000 people in the United States.
  • Orphan diseases are often serious or life threatening. In 1983, the U.S. government passed a law, called the Orphan Drug Act, to give drug companies certain financial benefits for developing orphan drugs that are safe and effective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: In which of the following can you observe time-dependent killing and prolonged post- antibiotic effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clindamycin 
 
  • Time dependent killing and prolonged post-antibiotic effect is seen with Clindamycin. 
  • Time dependent killing with short post-antibiotic effect is seen with b-lactam antibiotics, vancomycin and flucytosine. They require continuous IV infusion or multiple dosing. 
  • Time dependent killing with prolonged post antibiotic effect- Protein synthesis inhibitors (except aminoglycosides and azithromycin) and azoles. 
  • Concentration dependent killing with prolonged post-antibiotic effect- Aminoglycosides, FQs, Metronidazole, Rifampicin and Amphotericin B. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 748.

choices.text: Decreasing binding affinity of the drug to target protein
Increasing binding affinity of the drug to non-target protein
Increasing number of interactions of drug with target protein

questions.text: The primary concern in drug designing is in ensuring  ______________________?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Increasing number of interactions of drug with target protein 
 
  • Identification of the target biomolecule is the starting point for new drug invention. A lead compound capable of interacting with the target is searched by applying diverse approaches.
  • It is then chemically modified to optimize parameters such as pharmacokinetic, pharmaceutical, toxicological and other characteristics.
  • One concern of drug designing is to improve the “fit” of the drug with the target and thus enhancing the high-affinity interactions with the target protein with the help of Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies of the drug-receptor complex.
  • The number interactions help in stimulating the desired result, the affinity of interaction as such doesn't change the desired outcome even if the affinity is increased.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: Choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Brimonidine decreases aqueous production

Brimonidine lowers IOP by reducing aqueous production and by increasing uveoscleral flow. Brimonidine is alpha-2 agonist therefore it causes vasoconstriction and inhibits aqueous humor production.

Option B- Latanoprost is a PGF2 alpha analogue which acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
Option C- Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug which acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Option D- Betaxolol is a beta 1 antagonist which acts by decreasing aqueous production.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168.

questions.text: Pick the Rho kinase inhibitor from the following options.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option1) Fasudil
 
  • Fasudil is a selective Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor. ROCK is an enzyme that plays an important role in mediating vasodilation and vascular remodeling in the pathogenesis of pulmonary hypertension.
  • ROCK induces vasoconstriction by phosphorylating the myosin-binding subunit of myosin light chain (MLC) phosphatase, thus decreasing MLC phosphatase activity and enhancing vascular smooth muscle contraction.

Option 2 Ranolazine novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride approaches the Na+ channel from the luminal side and blocks it—reducing the lumen negative transepithelial potential difference which governs K+ and H+ secretion
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: Which one of the following does not cause lung infections?
questions.solution:
Rapidly growing atypical Mycobacteria causing lung infections are M. chelonie, M. fortuitum and M. abscessus. Mycobacterium marinum causes swimming pool granuloma seen in fish tank handlers. It involves skin in a sporotrichoid pattern. Tap water is believed to be its reservoir.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 367.

questions.text: Pick the option that is a special stain used to diagnose fungal hyphae in tissues?
questions.solution:
Gomori's methenanime silver stain is used to diagnose fungal hyphae in tissues.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman admits to having a sore throat for three days as well as a fever and headache. She was discovered to be highly dehydrated, had a blood pressure reading of 90/50 mm Hg, and had little red spots on the distal part of the cuff. What is the most likely etiological factor that is generating these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Neisseria meningitidis.

It is characterized by fever, nausea, nuchal rigidity with signs of endotoxemia such as petechiae, purpura, ecchymosis.

Neisseria meningitis is a gram negative cocci which is a normal flora of nasopharynx. However, the most common route of spread to CNS is via hematogenous route. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: Two hours after ingesting insecticide, a 24-year-old female from a rural location is taken to the emergency room complaining of nausea, vomiting, and shortness of breath. Upon examination, the patient has razor-sharp pupils and is releasing a kerosene-like odour. Which of the following regarding this patient's care is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atropine reverses respiratory muscle weakness

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor blocker, used to revert the bradycardia and hypotension but It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is mediated by nicotinic receptor.

Option 2,3 and 4 are all Correct statement regarding the treatment of Organophosphate poisoning.

The given features are suggestive of organophosphorus poisoning. They have a characteristic pungent kerosene like odor. Organophosphorus compounds irreversibly inhibit acetyl cholinesterase decreasing its activity.

*ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING:
Local muscarinic manifestations at the site of exposure (skin, eye, g.i.t.) occur immediately and are followed by complex systemic effects due to muscarinic, nicotinic and central actions. They are—
  • Irritation of eye, lacrimation, salivation, sweating, copious tracheobronchial secretions, miosis, blurring of vision, bronchospasm, breathlessness, colic, involuntary defecation and urination.
  • Fall in BP, bradycardia or tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, vascular collapse.
  • Muscular fasciculations, weakness, respiratory paralysis (central as well as peripheral).
  • Irritability, disorientation, unsteadiness, tremor, ataxia, convulsions, coma and death.
  • Death is generally due to respiratory failure.
*TREATMENT OF ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING:
  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison—fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastriclavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures—maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes—
             (a) Atropine It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear.
            (b) Cholinesterase reactivators Pralidoximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

questions.text: The prevalence of a disease in a population is estimated to be 50%. A range of 45 to 55% with 95% certainty is of interest to an investigator. The study needs a minimum sample size of:
questions.solution:
Step 1: Determine the population size (N): An accurate calculation requires knowledge of the population size; however, if the population size is unknown, an estimate can be used.


Step 2: Calculate the margin of error (E).
E can be calculated using the formula,
E = Z*√(p*(1-p))/√n, where
Z is the desired level of confidence (1.96 for 95% confidence),
p is the desired prevalence (0.50 for 50%), and
n is the desired sample size.


Step 3: Calculate the sample size (n).
The sample size can be calculated using the following equation:
n = (Z^2 * p * (1-p))/E^2, where
Z is the desired level of confidence (1.96 for 95% confidence),
p is the desired proportion (0.50 for 50%), and
E is the desired margin of error (0.05 for 45-55%).

The resulting sample size for a 95% confidence interval with an expected 50% prevalence and an allowable margin of error of 5% is 384.

Note: The error of margin in a any study is allowed to be upto 5%.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 22.

questions.text: In a population of 100 people, 80% are found to be infected with Candida glabrata. What will the range of prevalence for the candida glabrata infection be if the test is repeated with a 95% confidence level?
questions.solution:
To calculate the range of prevalence for Candida glabrata infection for 95% confidence levels we will use the formula for Binomial Confidence Intervals:

 Lower Limit = n * (p - Zα*sqrt(p*(1-p)/n)}
 
 Upper Limit = n * (p + Zα*sqrt(p*(1-p)/n)}

Where,

n = total number of individuals in the population

p = observed prevalence of the infection

Zα = The alpha level associated with the confidence interval (usually 1.96 for 95% confidence)

For this example,

n = 100

p = 80%

Zα = 1.96

Therefore, Lower Limit = 100 * (0.8 - 1.96*sqrt(0.8*(1-0.8)/100)} = 72.72%
Upper Limit = 100 * (0.8 + 1.96*sqrt(0.8*(1 - 0.8)/100)} = 87.28%

Therefore, the range of prevalence for Candida glabrata infection for 95% confidence level is 72.72% to 87.28%.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 22.

questions.text: Which disease is not included in the "Integrated Disease Surveillance Project"?
questions.solution:
Under IDSP Clinical data collection has been simplified as only the number of the cases of disease under surveillance is to be reported.

As of the latest updates, the IDSP focuses on around 33 specific diseases. These include high-priority diseases like:

  1. Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI)
  2. Tuberculosis
  3. Malaria
  4. Dengue
  5. Leptospirosis
  6. Cholera
  7. Hepatitis
  8. Typhoid
  9. Japanese Encephalitis
  10. Zika Virus, among others.
 

Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP)

Objectives
  • To strengthen/maintain decentralized laboratory-based IT enabled disease surveillance system for epidemic-prone diseases to monitor disease trends and to detect and respond to outbreaks in early rising phase through trained Rapid Response Team (RRTs).
Programme Components
  • Integration and decentralization of surveillance activities through the establishment of surveillance units at Centre, State and District level.
  • Human Resource Development – Training of State Surveillance Officers, District Surveillance Officers, Rapid Response Team and other Medical and Paramedical staff on principles of disease surveillance.
  • Use of Information Communication Technology for collection, collation, compilation, analysis and dissemination of data.
  • Strengthening of public health laboratories.
  • Inter sectoral Co-ordination for zoonotic diseases.

Hence, the option (1) is correct. Snake bite is not included under IDSP.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 546.

questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: TEE is more sensitive in picking up left atrial appendage thrombus.

Transesophageal echocardiography-
  • Type of echocardiography which utilizes an endoscopic transducer that is advanced into the thoracic esophagus, 
  • It offers superior visualization of the great vessels such as descending aorta, pulmonary artery and veins along with posterior cardiac structures as compared to standard transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).


Although transthoracic echocardiography remains the cornerstone of diagnostic cardiac ultrasound, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is a valuable complementary tool.

As compared with transthoracic echocardiography, TEE offers superior visualization of posterior cardiac structures because of close proximity of the esophagus to the posteromedial heart with lack of intervening lung and bone.

questions.text: A boy came in with a three- day history of vomiting, headaches, and fever as well as one day of dizziness. Exam results for neck stiffness were positive. questions.text: Regular evaluation of a 17- year-old child with no symptoms reveals a short PR interval and a delta wave on the ECG. The boy would benefit the least from which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Beta blocker
Short  PR/Delta waves point to WPW syndrome (characterised by a presence of Presence of an accessory conduction pathway)
Digitalis, beta blockers, and calcium channel blockers are effective in inhibiting conduction through the AV node; however, they do not impede conduction over most accessory pathways.
Drugs like Beta Blockers may actually reduce the refractory period of an accessory pathway which could lead to a faster ventricular rate (and a risk of ventricular fibrillation and hemodynamic collapse) if administered to individuals suffering from WPW syndrome.
Hence, Beta blockers are NOT Given to individuals with WPW Syndrome

WPW(Wolff–Parkinson–White) syndrome
  • Presence of an accessory conduction pathway (usually in left atrium/free wall of left ventricle)
  • Impulse conduction through the accessory pathway leads to earlier pre-excitation of ventricles since there is no AV nodal delay and ventricular contraction.
ECG Changes
  1. Decreased PR interval -because of earlier ventricular depolarisation and excitation.
  2. Prolonged QRS - since conduction is via accesory pathyway - not AV node. 
  3. DELTA WAVE - initial slurred upstroke of QRS (arrow)




Reference: Chhabra L, Goyal A, Benham MD. Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Aug 7]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554437/

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics makes it easier to tell seizures as compared to syncope?
questions.solution:
The characteristic that makes it easier to distinguish seizures from syncope is Urinary incontinence (option 3).

Here's why:

  • Seizures often involve involuntary movements, loss of motor control, and autonomic disturbances like urinary incontinence. It's not uncommon for someone to lose bladder control during a seizure, particularly in generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

  • Syncope, on the other hand, typically involves a transient loss of consciousness due to a sudden drop in blood flow to the brain, but urinary incontinence is much less common in syncope.

Let's quickly review the other options:

  1. Loss of consciousness: Both seizures and syncope involve a loss of consciousness, so this is not a distinguishing factor.
  2. Injury due to fall: Both seizures and syncope can result in a fall and injury, though the mechanisms differ (seizures due to uncontrolled movement, syncope due to collapse from a sudden drop in blood pressure). This doesn't reliably distinguish between the two.
  3. Urinary incontinence: As explained above, this is more commonly seen in seizures than syncope, making it a helpful distinguishing feature.
  4. Physical weakness with clear sensorium: This is more suggestive of syncope, as people usually regain full awareness shortly after syncope. In seizures, the postictal state (after the seizure) often involves confusion or altered consciousness.

So, urinary incontinence is the key feature that points more toward seizures than syncope.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3315.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective tool for malabsorption research?
questions.solution:
13 C Triclosan is used for bad oral odor, not used in malabsorption.
 
  • The D-xylose absorption test is used in evaluation of malabsorption syndromes.
 
  • The 14 C-triolein and trioctanoin breath test is used for fat malabsorption.
 
  • The triolein breath test provided the most reliable discrimination, with 100% sensitivity and 96% specificity. The trioctanoin and tripalmitin breath tests were sensitive, but lacked specificity




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2468.

Young, Alix et al. “A study of triclosan and its solubilizers as inhibitors of oral malodour.” Journal of clinical periodontology vol. 29,12 (2002): 1078-81. doi:10.1034/j.1600-051x.2002.291205.x.URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12492907/

Newcomer, A D et al. “Triolein breath test: a sensitive and specific test for fat malabsorption.” Gastroenterology vol. 76,1 (1979): 6-13. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/758149/

questions.text: Which of the following modes of treatment has demonstrated the best seizure-free duration in medically untreatable seizures?
questions.solution:
The most effective treatment for medically intractable seizures that shows best seizure-free period includes Resective epilepsy surgery. 
 
  • Advances in presurgical evaluation and microsurgical techniques have led to a steady increase in the success of epilepsy surgery. For example, ~70% of well-selected patients treated with temporal lobectomy will become seizure free, and another 15–25% will have at least a 90% reduction in seizure frequency.
  • Marked improvement is also usually seen in patients treated with hemispherectomy for catastrophic seizure disorders due to large hemispheric abnormalities.
  • Postoperatively, patients generally need to remain on antiseizure drug therapy, but the marked reduction of seizures following resective surgery can have a very beneficial effect on quality of life.

Additional treatments that may improve seizure control include corticosteroids, antiepileptic drugs, and gamma ray radiosurgery. However, these treatments may only reduce seizure frequency or severity, but may not achieve complete seizure freedom.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3321.

questions.text: Which of these is Bilateral Babinski sign a characteristic of?
questions.solution:
• The bilateral Babinski sign is an important sign of pontine haemorrhage due to damage to nerve tracts that run through the pons. This typically presents as an extensor response of the toes (upward) when the sole of the foot is firmly stroked.
  • It is essential for clinicians to be aware of this sign as it can indicate the severity of the pontine haemorrhage and may provide important information on the patient's neurological prognosis.
  • In cases of pontine hemorrhage, the presence of a bilateral Babinski sign should be an alarm for clinicians to consider an urgent intervention such as a surgical evacuation of the hematoma.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 165.
Rao, Gurukanth; Vaibhav, S.; Belle, Jayaprakash. A Case of Resolving Pontine Hemorrhage. APIK Journal of Internal Medicine 12(3):p 186-188, Jul–Sep 2024. | DOI: 10.4103/ajim.ajim_34_22. URL: https://journals.lww.com/joim/fulltext/2024/12030/a_case_of_resolving_pontine_hemorrhage.11.aspx

questions.text: For which of the following is Left bundle branch block (LBBB) on ECG least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
LBBB occurs when normal electrical activity in His-Purkinje system is interrupted.
It occurs in patients with underlying heart disease and may be associated with progressive conducting system disease.

Causes of LBBB:

• Structural heart diseases
• Primary disease of cardiac electrical and Coronary artery disease conduction system
• Dilated cardiomyopathies
• Long standing hypertension leading to aortic root dilation
• Hyperkalemia



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 349, 350, 1896, 1897.

questions.text: The most prevalent kind of young-onset diabetes (MODY) is characterised by the following genetic mutation:

Genetic defects of beta cell function characterized by mutations in:

4. Insulin promoter factor-1 (IPF-1; MODY 4)

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the brain is NOT connected with atrophy due to HIV infection?
questions.solution:
HIV dementia is characterized by 
  • Subcortical dementia, with white matter involvement,
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Demyelination
Immunohistochemistry studies show that the virus is most densely located in the basal ganglia, subcortical regions, and frontal cortex.

Radiographic imaging reveals:
  • Cerebral atrophy and particularly
  • Prominent atrophy of the caudate region.
The cingulate gyrus is not usually involved. 



Reference: Saylor, Deanna et al. “HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder--pathogenesis and prospects for treatment.” Nature reviews. Neurology vol. 12,4 (2016): 234-48. doi:10.1038/nrneurol.2016.27. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4937456/

questions.text: With pCO2-30, pO2-115, [HCO3-]- 20 and pH-7.45 revealed in an arterial blood gas analysis, the patient is likely dealing with:
questions.solution:
• The pH of 7.45 is at the upper limit of normal signifying a trend toward Alkalosis. 
  • pCO2 is low (less than 35) at 30 - suggesting the cause for Respiratory alkalosis. 
  • Alveolar hyperventilation decreases Paco2 and increases the HCO3−/ Paco2 ratio, thus increasing pH. Non-bicarbonate cellular buffers respond by consuming HCO3−. Hypocapnia develops when a sufficiently strong ventilatory stimulus causes CO2 output in the lungs to exceed its metabolic production by tissues. Plasma pH and [HCO3−] appear to vary proportionately with Paco2 over a range from 40–15 mmHg.

Summary of Acid-Base disorders: 


Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 368.

questions.text: Renal failure is apparent in a 55-year-old male. He reports a seven-year history of minor bone discomfort. The pelvis's X-ray reveals osteolytic lesions. Using serum electrophoresis, an M spike is seen. Evaluation of the peripheral blood revealed more than 35% plasma cells. An increase in plasma cells with abnormal antigen expression was detected in the bone marrow. The following is the most likely cause:
What is the correct diagnosis of a patient whose serum has positive HBsAg and HBeAg?
questions.solution:
Correct diagnosis of patient whose serum has positiveHBSAg a n d HBeAg is acute infective hepatitis.
The various viral antigen-antibody markers used in the diagnosis and monitoring of hepatitis infection include:

1. Hepatitis A IgM antibody: This antibody is present during the acute phase of hepatitis A infection, indicating recent infection.

2. Hepatitis B Surface Antigen (HBsAg): This is the first and most important marker for detecting active hepatitis B infection. If this antigen is present in the blood, it indicates the presence of the virus in the body.

3. Hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc): This antibody is produced in response to the core (interior) of the hepatitis B virus and indicates current or recent infection.

4. Hepatitis B e Antigen (HBeAg): The presence of this antigen in the blood suggests an active hepatitis B infection with high viral load and can be used to determine the need for treatment.

5. Hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs): This antibody indicates immunity to the virus, either due to past infection or vaccination.

6. Hepatitis C antibody (anti-HCV): This detects infection with the hepatitis C virus and can be used to diagnose the infection and monitor response to treatment.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 552.

choices.text: As anti-ACHR is negative you will consider an alternative diagnosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complained of ptosis, chewing difficulties, and occasionally had trouble swallowing. No prior instances of vision loss exist. With a finger abduction test at a 60° angle, there is symmetric ptosis and a slight restriction of extraocular muscle movement causing diplopia. Only the orbicularis exhibits a decreasing response in a nerve conduction examination. An ERG pattern was myopathic. Radioimmunoassay for anti-AchR proved ineffective. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Generalized myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This condition commonly causes ptosis and diplopia as initial complaints and reveals a characteristic pattern of muscle weakness.


Clinical features:
 
  • The distribution of muscle weakness often has a characteristic pattern. The cranial muscles, particularly the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs), are typically involved early in the course of MG; diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints.
  • Facial weakness produces a“snarling” expression when the patient attempts to smile.
  • Weakness in chewing is most noticeable after prolonged effort, as in chewing meat
  • Difficulty in swallowing may occur as a result of weakness of the palate, tongue, or pharynx, giving rise to nasal regurgitation or aspiration of liquids or food.

Autoantibodies Associated with MG:
  • Anti-AChR antibodies are detectable in the serum of ~85% of all myasthenic patients but in only ~50% of patients with weakness confined to the ocular muscles.
  • The presence of anti-AChR antibodies is virtually diagnostic of MG, but a negative test does not exclude the disease.
  • The measured level of anti-AChR antibody does not correspond well with the severity of MG in different patients.
  • Antibodies to MuSK are present in ~40% of AChR antibody–negative patients with generalized MG.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

choices.text: Combination chemotherapy should be given in patient above 50 years of age

questions.text: Pick the correct option regarding treatment of CLL.
A young man with impaired eyesight and a history of recurrent epididymitis complains of painful mouth and glans penis ulcers. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Behcet's disease

Behcet's disease is a chronic relapsing autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent painful oral ulcerations, penile ulcerations, and visual disturbances, associated with the presence of HLA-B51.

Symptoms typically begin in young individuals, affect both men and women equally, and involve inflammation of both small and large vessels.

International Study Group Criteria for Diagnosis of Behcet Syndrome:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2817.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who smoked 5 packs a day for 11 years has been diagnosed with lung cancer. The tumor was shown to have tiny, highly mitotic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei through histologic analysis. Which of the following clinical manifestations could the patient experience while they are ill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thin limbs and obese trunks
 
  • The biopsy of the patient, who is a 60-year-old male with a history of 55 pack years and presented with chronic cough, revealed small hyperchromatic nuclei and highly mitotic cells–findings which are suggestive of Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC).
  • Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli (see Fig. 15.43C). The cells are round, oval, or spindle shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell cancer lungs- SIADH, Cushing's syndrome(given in the question), Lambert-Eaton syndrome, anemia, etc. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 721.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient initially experiences brief vision occlusion for two to three days before experiencing an abrupt loss of vision. Which of the following tests would be most effective in assessing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Serum creatinine levels

Serum creatinine levels would be the best choice as DM can lead to both retinopathy and nephropathy.

Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired.

It has been widely accepted that ACR is a frequently used laboratory index to diagnose DN and distinguish early-stage (30 mg/g < ACR < 300mg/g) and advanced-stage (ACR > 300 mg/g) DN. Based on ACR levels, DN patients were divided into four subgroups of early-stage DN, early-stage DN combined with DR, advanced-stage DN, and advanced-stage DN patients DR.
New studies shows correlation with s homocysteine and DR.
Online Reference:
Huang K, Liang Y, Wang K, Ma Y, Wu J, Luo H, Yi B. Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired. Front Clin Diabetes Healthc. 2022 May 12;3:831128. doi: 10.3389/fcdhc.2022.831128. PMID: 36992775; PMCID: PMC10012155.

questions.text: Which of the following medications can effectively treat juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in a female of childbearing age group in substitution of sodium valproate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Levetiracetam
 
  • Levetiracetam can be prescribed as monotherapy in a female patient of childbearing age as a replacement of valproate for JME, because of no known significant drug interactions. Rest options have their fare risk of adverse effects associated.
  • Carbamazepine and phenytoin are in fact contraindicated in JME. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 401.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a major criteria in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
According to Modified Jones criteria, Major criteria include- Polyarthritis, myocarditis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema Nodosum and Sydenham's chorea. While Polyarthalgia comes in minor criteria in Low risk population.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2769.

questions.text: An older, hypertensive patient is experiencing sudden onset headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity without a specific neurological abnormality. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly, hypertensive patient presented with sudden onset headache, vomiting, neck rigidity without focal neurological deficit, diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Features of SAH would include- 

1. Sudden, severe headache
2. Stiff neck
3. Nausea and vomiting
4. Decreased alertness, confusion
5. Seizures
6. Vision changes, such as blurred or double vision
7. Loss of consciousness
8. Facial weakness
9. Weakness or numbness in an arm or leg
10. Difficulty speaking or understanding speech



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true about treatment with iodine.
questions.solution:
Iodine is not contraindicated in hyperthyroidism. Although use of iodine in hyperthyroidism is controversial, studies have suggested that iodine can worsen the condition in some cases, and it is not recommended for use except in extreme cases.

  • Iodine supplements are generally only used after other treatments, such as antithyroid medications and surgery, have failed to adequately control the symptoms.
  • In these cases, high doses of iodine can be used to temporarily shut down the thyroid, allowing time for other treatments to take effect and to alleviate symptoms.
  • Iodide can be used in Thyrotoxicosis also. Stable iodide (5 drops SSKI every 6 h) is given to block thyroid hormone synthesis via the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2941, 2942.

questions.text: Which part of the brain is most likely to experience atrophy in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Temporoparietal

  • In Alzheimer's disease, the part of the brain most likely to experience atrophy is the temporoparietal region.
  • This area is involved in cognitive functions such as memory, language, and spatial orientation, which are commonly affected in Alzheimer's disease.
 
  • In typical amnestic AD, brain atrophy begins in the medial temporal lobes before spreading to the inferior temporal, lateral, medial parietal, and dorsolateral frontal cortices.
  • The pattern of binding is largely consistent with Braak neuropathologic staging of NFTs, with early retention in medial temporal regions, followed by spread into temporoparietal and cingulate cortices, dorsolateral prefrontal regions, and, ultimately, primary sensory and motor areas.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3370, 3371.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is bumping into things and is experiencing acute onset amnesia. Upon assessment, she displayed normal comprehension, fluency of speaking, and alertness. Additional testing found difficulties identifying the fingers, right-left confusion, impaired arithmetic skills, and impaired writing (acalculia). MRI results showed leptomeningeal augmentation and foci of increased cortical and subcortical T2 signals. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
• Gerstman syndrome is a neurological disorder caused by damage to the dominant hemisphere of the Parietal lobe which results in symptoms including difficulty with simple arithmetic, difficulty with writing, difficulty naming individual fingers, and difficulty telling the difference between the right and left side of the body.
 
  • It is commonly associated with damage to the inferior parietal lobule, specifically the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe. 


Principal features of Gerstman syndrome:
 
  1. Acalculia
  2. Alexia
  3. Finger agnosia
  4. Right-left confusion



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3326.

questions.text: Pick the statement that is not correct regarding iron deficiency anemia.
The incidence of which of the following has been reduced due to the revolutionized in food preservation brought on by the advent of refrigeration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Stomach
 
  • Since the early 20th century, countries that have substituted refrigeration for traditional food-preserving methods such as salting, smoking, and pickling have seen a remarkable decrease in stomach cancer cases.
  • Conversely, countries that still rely heavily on these old practices still have high incidences of stomach cancer.
  • Stomach cancer increases with consumption of nitrites, preserved food, etc also. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 204.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who had a firm, non-tender breast lump underwent fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Which of the following traits would lead one to believe a benign breast illness has been discovered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)  Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei

A non-tender, firm and mobile breast lump in a female age 17 years is suggestive of fibroadenoma, in which tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei are seen on FNAC.
