questions.text: Pick the right immunohistochemical marker that can be used for the diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Desmin
 
  • Desmin is a protein that is normally expressed in skeletal muscle cells and can be used to clinically diagnose rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Desmin expression is nearly ubiquitous in normal skeletal muscle cells and helps to maintain their structural integrity. 
  • Immunohistochemistry staining for desmin can therefore be used as a diagnostic tool to identify and distinguish rhabdomyosarcoma from other types of cancers.
  • Additionally, desmin expression can also be assessed in biopsy samples to determine the extent of tumor spread and monitor treatment response.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1212.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male with 35 pack years appeared with a microscopic hematuria and a painless lump in the left scrotal sac. Alpha- fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase tests in the lab came out negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The features provided of a 55-year old man with history of 35 pack years of smoking and painless swelling in the left scrotal sac (may be metastatic mass) and microscopic hematuria (suggestive of RCC), laboratory investigations of negative Alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase levels (ruling out any testicular tumor) points towards a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. This may result in a varicocele formation which may present as a lump in the scrotum

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2090.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of passage of drops of blood through the rectum in a toddler?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of passage of a few drops of blood per rectum in a toddler is Juvenile rectal polyp.
  • Juvenile polyps are the most common form of colorectal hamartoma and are mostly found in children under the age of 5.
  • It occurs due to SMAD 4 mutation. 
  • They usually present as a single lesion in the rectum and may cause rectal bleeding, mucus discharge, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • They are also known as retention polyps due to their occurrence as a result of the obstruction of the crypt necks leading to dilation of the mucus-filled glands.

There is no increased risk of cancer associated with juvenile polyps


Reference:Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition Page no 805

questions.text: Hot spot on Tc-99 is observed in the following parotid tumor:
questions.solution:
• Hot spot on Tc-99 is seen in Adenolymphoma or Warthin's Tumor ( referred to as Papillary cystadenoma Lymphomatosum ).

  • It is second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland  characterized by both epithelial and lymphoid elements. It is more common in males in the 5th to 7th decade, with a possible association with smoking, and occurs exclusively in the parotid gland overlying the mandible angle.

  • It is usually bilateral (10%) and slow growing and while never malignant, it usually shows a 'hot' spot on 99m Te-pertechnate scan, which is a peculiar feature distinct from other parotid tumors which usually show a 'cold' spot.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Where does osteoblastic metastasis commonly originate?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Prostate
 
  • Sclerotic or osteoblastic bone metastases are distant tumor deposits of a primary tumor within bone characterized by new bone deposition or new bone formation.
  • Sclerotic bone metastases can arise from several different primary malignancies including- prostate carcinoma (most common) breast carcinoma (may be mixed) transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) carcinoid medulloblastoma neuroblastoma mucinous adenocarcinoma of the gastrointestinal tract lymphoma (e.g. ivory vertebra).

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 516.

choices.text: Minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitive surgery later
Maximum possible surgical intervention is done immediately

questions.text: Which of these is true about damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitive surgery later

Damage control surgery (DCS) is an approach of treating trauma patients with major injuries.

It can be divided into the following three phases: Initial laparotomy, Intensive Care Unit (ICU) resuscitation, and definitive reconstruction. 

Abbreviated laparotomy involves temporarily packing and closure of the abdomen to prevent further physiological complications caused by delayed shock and excessive hemorrhage.


Fig: Abdominal closure following damage control surgery

* [Extra Edge]: Damage Control Surgery
 
  • Damage control surgery aims to break the ‘vicious cycle’ of hypothermia, tissue hypoxia, coagulopathy and acidosis before later definitive repair. This is called " Trauma Triad of Death". Anatomy is restored when the physiology is optimised.
  • The principles are in sequence: (i) short operations aiming to control haemorrhage and limit contamination; (ii) ongoing correction of deranged physiology – acidosis, hypothermia, perfusion and organ function on intensive care; (iii) definitive surgical repair.
  • This is a key component of damage control resuscitation. The decision of whether damage control surgery is the appropriate course should be made early and allows the whole surgical and anaesthetic team to work together to limit the time in surgery and achieve the earliest possible admission of the patient to the ICU. Damage control is a staged process.

Fig: Trauma Triad Of Death
 
Stage Intervention
I Patient selection
II Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
III Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
IV Definitive surgery
V Abdominal closure
Fig: Stages of DCS


Fig: Criteria for Damage Control Surgery


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 385.

questions.text: To treat breast cancer, a patient had sentinel lymph node biopsy. Which nerve is most likely to sustain damage during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intercostobrachial nerve
 
  • Sentinel node biopsy for breast cancer often causes injury to the intercostobrachial nerve during axillary dissection to clear the lymph nodes, while taking care to preserve the nerve of serratus anterior, thoracodorsal vessels, nerve of latissimus dorsi, and medial/lateral pectoral nerves.
  • Intercostobrachial nerve is often sacrificed during the operation, resulting in loss of sensation on the upper medial border of the arm. ALND is more likely than SLND to lead to axillary paresthesias, because of disruption to the intercostobrachial nerves.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: What do we call the highly vascular tumor of brain and spinal cord in adults?
questions.solution:
Hemangioblastoma is a highly vascular tumor of brain and spinal cord in adults.
Hemangioblastoma represents the most common primary intra-axial tumor in the adult posterior fossa.
It occur almost exclusively in the posterior fossa (cerebellum) as a solid or cystic with a mural nodule.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1896.

choices.text: Located retroperitoneally at the level of L3
Useful for the painful conditions of lower abdomen
Most common side effects are diarrhea and hypotension

questions.text: Pick the option that is true about coeliac plexus block.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. Most common side effects are diarrhea and hypotension

Celiac Plexus Block is performed retroperitoneally at the level of L1 and is usually done bilaterally for  painful conditions of upper abdomen like pancreatic cancer or pancreatitis.
Most common side effects are diarrhea and hypotension.
 
  • Celiac plexus neurolysis with alcohol injection has been an effective form of analgesic treatment in patients with pancreatic carcinoma.
  • However, the use of radiologically or endoscopically guided celiac plexus blockade in chronic pancreatitis has been disappointing.
  • Due to the risk of alcohol injury and the need for repeated injections, celiac plexus blockade in chronic pancreatitis has used short-acting analgesics or other drugs rather than 50% alcohol.
  • A trial of EUS-guided celiac plexus blockade revealed successful pain relief in 55% of patients, but the benefit lasted beyond 6 months in only 10% of patients. The procedure therefore appears safe, but the effect is short lived in those patients who obtain pain relief.
Other options-
  • Coeliac plexus is located L1
  • It is done bilaterally
  • It is used for painful conditions of upper abdomen 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1469.

questions.text: What is the mortality rate associated with emergency abdominal aortic surgery for RAAA(Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms)?
questions.solution:
By providing adequate preoperative cardiac evaluation and close postoperative monitoring, the mortality rate for elective operative treatment is about 1-2%.

However, for those who experience an acute rupture, the fatality rate for emergency operations reaches 45-50%.

An alternative method of endovascular repair with stent placement is becoming more commonplace, however, it presently carries a mortality rate of approximately 40%.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: What is the mortality rate associated with emergency abdominal aortic surgery for ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: >50
 
  • Emergency abdominal aortic surgery for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is a high-risk procedure associated with significant mortality.
  • The mortality rate for this procedure is generally greater than 50%.
  • Options A, B, and C underestimate the mortality rate associated with this surgical intervention.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: Boiling water accidently splashes over the face and trunk of a 5-year-old child. Which of the following techniques is best for calculating the amount of body surface affected by burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lund and Browder chart
 
  • When estimating burn size in young children, the head size must be taken into consideration as it has a larger relative surface area than other parts of the body.
  • The Lund and Browder chart can be used to get a more precise understanding of the actual burn size in children up to 5 yrs of age.
  • The body proportions of children necessitate adjustment of the above-mentioned scales. An infant’s head is proportionally larger than an adult’s and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each. For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.
  • The Lund and Browder chart can be completed at multiple points during a burn admission to document changes in burn size/depth and can also be used as an adjunct to surgical notes, when skin graft donor sites and grafted areas can be shaded.
* History:

Berkow reported the following proportions for adults, noting that they were not difficult for clinicians to remember: 1) lower extremities, 38 %; 2) trunk, 38 %; 3) upper extremities, 18 %; and 4) head, 6 %.
He concluded that 'if one bears these proportions in mind, estimating the extensiveness of a lesion is a very simple matter.
Furthermore, Berkow detailed why these adult proportions did not hold true for infants and children. Berkow's method for calculating surface area of various body parts in relation to TBSA was instrumental in later efforts by Doctors Lund and Browder (1944) in the development of the Lund-Browder Chart and by Wallace (1951) who simplified burn BSA assessment, resulting in the Rule of Nine or Wallace's rule of nines.



Fig: Modified Lund and Browder table and diagram

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: A three-year-old child has burns on their face and scalp with singeing of hairs , buttocks, and both thighs circumferentially. How much of the body's surface area is affected by burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 37
 
  • For child below 5 years usually Modified Lund and Browder table is used, but for simplicity of calculations:
  • An infant’s head is proportionally larger than an adult’s and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each.
  • For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.
In the given question , closest answer is-37%
  • Circumferential burn of both thighs = 6 . 5 + 6.5 = 13
  • Buttocks= 2.5 +2.5 =5
  • Face and scalp with singeing of hairs = 17
  • Total burn area= 13+5+17= 35%

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Newborn with meningomyelocele has been listed for surgery. The defect should be repaired right away with:
questions.solution:
Meningomyelocele is a caudal NTD which requires prompt and correct management from a skilled team in order to improve the chances of survival.
  • Surgical correction should be performed within 48 hours of delivery, and the infant should be placed in a prone position with a non-adherent, sterile saline dressing and a plastic shield wrap in order to maintain moisture and protect the defect from drying, trauma, and infection.Saline dressing helps to keep the exposed neural tissue moist and prevents infection while minimizing irritation
  • Early treatment and support will provide the best chance of recovery.



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3066-3068

questions.text: Pick the option that is an early complication of ileostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Necrosis

Stoma necrosis may occur in the early post-operative period and usually is caused by skeletonizing the distal small bowel and/or creating an overly tight fascial defect.
Rest of the given options are delayed complications of ileostomy. 

* Stoma complications:

Skin irritation
Prolapse
Retraction
Ischemia
Stenosis
Parastomal hernia
Bleeding
Fistulation

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1314.

questions.text: In order to prevent an accident, a seatbelt-wearing motorist abruptly applied the brakes. Which body part has the highest chance of suffering an injury?
questions.solution:
In the event of a car accident in which a seatbelt is worn, rapid deceleration can lead to a mesentery tear, which is also the most common organ to be injured in seat belt trauma.

Trauma to the abdomen from the seatbelt may squeeze the pancreas on the vertebral column and cause pancreatico-duodenal damage.

An exploratory surgery may be required if there is any discoloration on the abdominal walls, or visible clothing creases on the abdominal skin.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: A patient who is a 55-year- old man, has a 4 to 5 cm tumour in his right neck. It was determined to be a cancer by FNAC. There were no tumours found during the clinical examination of the larynx, pharynx, hypopharynx, and oral cavity. Except for the neck tumour, a full body PET scan did not reveal any enhanced uptake. An unidentified main diagnosis was made. The tumor's TNM status, as determined by the AJCC system of classification, would be:
questions.solution:
According to the American Joint Committee on Cancer Stages of Regional Lymph Node Involvement the TNM status would be - Tx: Unknown Primary (T status cannot be assessed) N2a: Metastasis in single ipsilateral LN, >3 cm but <6 cm in greatest dimension. Mx: Unknown presence or absence of metastasis.

Reference: AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, Eighth Edition, Page No 61.

questions.text: A 48-year- old female presents with pain in left flank, recurrent gross hematuria, and seizure. A CT scan of the abdomen showed several right sided renal angiomyolipomas measuring 1.5 to 6.5 cm and a left perinephric hematoma with a 3 cm angiomyolipoma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tuberous sclerosis (TS), also known as tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or Bourneville disease, is a phakomatosis (neurocutaneous disorder) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system).
 

Spontaneous mutations account for 50-86% of cases, with the remainder inherited as an autosomal dominant condition. In the majority of such cases (80%) the mutation has been narrowed down to two tumor suppressor genes, both part of the mTOR pathway.

  • TSC1: encoding hamartin, on chromosome 9q32-34

  • TSC2: encoding tuberin, on chromosome 16p13.3 (accounts for most cases)

    * Tuberous sclerosis has a significant number of manifestations, involving many organ systems. The most common radiographic manifestations are:

 

  • cortical or subependymal tubers and white matter abnormalities

  • renal angiomyolipomas

  • cardiac rhabdomyoma(s)

    Tuberous Sclerosis also has dermatological manifestations like adenoma sebaceum and Shagreen's patch. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with psychological disorder is facing left-sided flank discomfort. Right kidney hyperechoic lesion and many liver lesions are seen on ultrasonography. These lesions had a -50 to -80 HU density, according to an abdominal CT scan. The following is the most likely reason:
questions.solution:
The lesions described in the question are s/o angiomyolipoma which appear hyperechoic on ultrasound and fat density hypoattenuating lesion ( black in appearance with HU of -60 to -80 ) on CT scan.
  • Tuberous sclerosis (TS), also known as tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or Bourneville disease, is a phakomatosis (neurocutaneous disorder) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system).
  • Spontaneous mutations account for 50-86% of cases, with the remainder inherited as an autosomal dominant condition. In the majority of such cases (80%) the mutation has been narrowed down to two tumor suppressor genes, both part of the mTOR pathway.
  • TSC1: encoding hamartin, on chromosome 9q32-34
  • TSC2: encoding tuberin, on chromosome 16p13.3 (accounts for most cases) Tuberous sclerosis has a significant number of manifestations, involving many organ systems.
  • The most common radiographic manifestations are: cortical or subependymal tubers and white matter abnormalities renal angiomyolipomas cardiac rhabdomyoma(s)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: A 3 cm labia majora ulcer with elevated edges was found in a 20-year-old young female patient. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the root cause of this ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct answer, option 2- Treponema pallidum

Among the given options only Herpes simplex causes genital ulcers but those are small, painful and multiple. In the question a large single ulcer is mentioned. 
Condition Appearance Symptoms Associated Signs
Herpes Simplex Virus Painful vesicles or ulcers Burning, itching, pain Lymphadenopathy, systemic symptoms (fever)

questions.text: Primary amenorrhea was discovered in a 16-year-old female with normal pubic hair and breast tissue. Upon examination, the uterus was gone, and the vagina was blind. What is the proper diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mullerian agenesis

Differential diagnosis between MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser) and AIS (androgen insensitivity syndrome)
MRKH AIS
Genotype XX Genotype XY
Normal female serum T levels Normal male T levels
Normal female pubic and axillary hair Decreased pubic and axillary hair
Normal female height Increased height compared with female counterparts
Normal ovaries located high on the pelvic side wall Intra-abdominal testicles
No increased risk of gonadal malignancy Gonads removal recommended after puberty due to increased risk of malignancy

Note: Milder forms of AIS might present a less affected phenotype.
Abbreviation: T. testosterone.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 143.

questions.text: For which of these condition given below is hormone replacement therapy not given?
questions.solution:
Prevention of CAD

Hormone replacement therapy can be useful in controlling menopausal symptoms (hot flashes,urogenital atrophy  etc.) and helping to prevent osteoporosis. 

It has also been suggested that although estrogen might reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, primarily by improving lipid profile or by vascular effects, estrogen may increase the injury resulting from ischemia, either by increased cell death pathways or by adverse remodeling.
 

Benefits Risks
Short term
• Controls symptoms during the menopause transition within days or weeks/improves mood
 		 • Oral HRT increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
• Increases the risk of CVD in women who start HRT after age 60 and in those who already have risk factors, such as smoking, being overweight, or having high blood pressure or high cholesterol
Long term
• Keeps bones healthy, reducing the risk of osteoporosis and fractures (broken bones)		 • Small increase in breast-cancer risk after age 60
• Reduces the risk of CVD (as long as HRT is started within 5-6 years of the menopause transition and there are no other risk factors) • Slight increase in the risk of gallbladder disease
•May protect against memory loss and possibly Alzheimer's disease
• Reduces the risk of boewl cancer		 Note: Some of these risks (for example, DVT) are not increased when oestrogen is administered by patch, gel or spray rather than as tablets.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91-94.

questions.text: Which of the following tests given below helps with fetal and maternal blood differentiation in a specimen?
questions.solution:
• The alkali denaturation test, also known as A or Apt test, is a medical test used to differentiate fetal or neonatal blood from maternal blood found in a newborn’s stool or vomit, or from maternal vaginal blood.
  • It is a qualitative test.

 
  • The Kleihauer–Betke test or acid elution test is a blood test used to measure the amount of fetal hemoglobin transferred from a fetus to a mother’s bloodstream.
  • It is a quantitative test.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 130, 131.

questions.text: Just after a regular vaginal delivery, a mother experienced severe shock. Most likely reason is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. PPH

PPH is one of the most serious complications of childbirth AND carries a high risk of mortality due to hemorrhage and shock.  

Other options are less common ones.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 737-739.

choices.text: PV examination to check uterus size of 6 weeks

questions.text: What is the most accurate and safest method to diagnose viable pregnancy at 6 weeks?
questions.solution:
• USG for fetal cardiac activity Cardiac activity is seen as early as the sixth week of gestation, when the embryo is 1-2 mm in size. 
  • The current guidelines of the Society of Radiologists in Ultrasound (SRU) establish a CRL cutoff of 7 mm, above which one should definitively visualize fetal cardiac activity.

Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 248,249

choices.text: Maternal side of the placenta presents at the vulva
Blood collects between the placenta and fetal membranes and escapes through vagina

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding Duncan placental separation?
questions.solution:
• There are two methods of separation and expulsion of the placenta.
  • Shultze Method: 80%: This is the most common method in which separation starts from the center of the placenta and with the aid of Retroplacental clot the placenta drops into the lower uterine segment or into the vagina. During delivery the fetal surface appears first at the vulva followed by the membranes. There is minimal blood loss with this method.
  • Mathews Duncan Method 20%: In this method separationstarts at the edge and slides down sideways. It comes through the vulva with the lateral border first, like a button through a button hole. The maternal surface is seen first at the vulva. There is trickling of blood throughout the third stage.
Memorizing Trick- 
Shultze- spell Cultze- Centre seperates first
Duncan- Diameter seperates first 


Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 412

questions.text: Which of the following gynaecological primary most frequently causes intraocular metastasis in females?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Breast
 
  • Breast Ocular metastasis can represent the initial manifestation of breast carcinoma, with up to 26% of orbital breast metastases presenting before the discovery of the primary tumor.
  • The most common primary sites of metastatic carcinoma to the orbit are the breast, lung, prostate, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney.
  • For breast carcinoma, the interval from primary diagnosis to orbital metastasis is 3–5 years.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1316.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhea, small stature, widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea are present in a 22-year-old female. The likely  Karyotype is
