choices.text: Direct injection of oxytocin after delivery of anterior shoulder

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the active management of the third stage of labor ?
questions.solution:
Delayed cord clamping is advised, not immediate cord clamping

Components of AMTSL:
  1. Administration of a uterotonic drug within 1 minute of birth of the baby (oxytocin 10 IU IM is the uterotonic of choice; in its absence, use 0.2 mg ergometrine IM or 1 mL syntometrine IM or 600 mcg misoprostol).
  2. Delayed cord clamping.
  3. Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction- Modified Brandt Andrews technique.
  4. Intermittent assessment of uterine Note: Earlier, uterine massage was the recommended 4th step in AMTSL. However, it is now a part of the treatment of PPH. The step which was never included in AMTSL was early cord clamping.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 506, 507.
Active Management of Third Stage of Labour, WHO guidelines (New Recommendations), URL: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/10665/119831/1/WHO_RHR_14.18_eng.pdf

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has a history of repeated abortions and history of calf pain. Congenital deficiencies of which of these is present in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Protein C
 
  • Protein C is a vitamin K-dependent glycoprotein synthesized by  liver that inactivates factors Va and VIlla. It is an anticoagulant and it's deficiency causes hypercoagulable state. Protein C deficiency is also an autosomal dominant genetic disorder that affects 3.2% of patients with venous thromboembolism.
 
  • Clinical signs and symptoms of Protein C deficiency vary and can range from mild to severe. Symptoms may include easy bruising and/or bleeding, superficial blood vessels that are visible on the skin, recurrent DVT ("deep vein thrombosis"), pulmonary embolism, recurrent miscarriages, stroke, or heart attack.
 
  • In infants, Protein C deficiency can cause a condition known as "purpura fulminans" which is characterized by severe abdominal pain, shock, and death within a few days of birth.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 976, 977.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 319, 376.

choices.text: Zidovudine given to mother antenatally and to neonate

questions.text: All of the following have no role in decreasing mother to child transmission of HIV except:
questions.solution:
Zidovudine (AZT): This antiretroviral medication, when given to HIV-positive pregnant women during pregnancy and to the newborn after birth, has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV. This is a standard intervention in preventing MTCT.

Breastfeeding: Breastfeeding by an HIV-positive mother can increase the risk of HIV transmission to the infant. In settings where safe alternatives to breastfeeding are available, they are recommended to prevent HIV transmission.

Vaginal delivery: Vaginal delivery can increase the risk of MTCT of HIV, especially if the mother has a high viral load. A cesarean section may be recommended in some cases to reduce this risk.

Vitamin A supplementation: While vitamin A is important for general health, it has not been shown to reduce the risk of MTCT of HIV. In fact, some studies suggest that high doses of vitamin A might increase the risk of transmission.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 498.

questions.text: A 30-year-old girl from a low socioeconomic class who lives in a hill station complains of amenorrhea, mild fever, loss of appetite, and frequent urination in addition to other symptoms including dysuria and hematuria. Her concerns are most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Genitourinary tuberculosis is very common in India.

Most common site of infection of genital tuberculosis is the fallopian tubes ( spreads from lungs via hematogenous route ) and the pathological process leads to blockage of tubes. Its features include -
1. Dysuria
2. Urinary frequency
3. Urinary urgency
4. Urinalysis may show pyuria and bacteriuria
5. Micturition pain
6. Weakness of stream
7. Genital ulcers
8. Hematuria
9. Flank pain
10. Low-grade fever

HSG- shows golf club appearance of Fallopian tubes. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 350, 351.

choices.text: Result in gaseous exchange and are involved in oxygenation in the fetus
Important role in lung growth and in the development of respiratory muscles.
Helps in the conditioning of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: With respect to fetal breathing movements , Which of the following is an incorrect statement?
questions.solution:
Option 1 - is an incorrect statement.

Fetal breathing movements refer to the chest movements seen on an Antenatal USG and is a component of Biophysical Profile .

Fetal breathing movements are not involved in fetal oxygenation and the fetus instead relies on the placenta for gaseous exchange/oxygenation rather than the lungs(lungs are collapsed in a fetus) -hence, option 1 is an incorrect statement.

Importance of foetal breathing movement is that it helps in development of respiratory system(option 2)/conditioning of respiratory muscles (option 4) and nervous system to prepare the foetus for breathing after birth. They tend to increase as gestational age increases and child approaches term gestation(option 3).

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th edition Page no 339-342

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy complains of increasing muscle weakness. On examination, his calves are bulky and show muscle tightening. His serum creatine kinase levels are increasing with age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The signs are indicative of Dystrophin deficiency causing Duchenne's Muscular dystrophy. Its other features include -

1. Progressive muscle weakness and wasting, beginning in the lower limbs.
2. Difficulty in ambulation due to leg weakness and contractures.
3. Abnormal gait and foot deformities, including contractures of the Achilles tendon and plantar fascia, toe walking, and hyperextension at the knees.
4. Low endurance, leading to fatigue and exhaustion early in physical activities.
5. Respiratory muscle weakness, leading to impaired pulmonary function.
6. Respiratory infections due to weak respiratory muscles.
7. Difficulty with fine eye movements
8. Cognitive deficits
9. Cardiomyopathy and progressive heart failure


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 589,590

choices.text: Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A 12 years old boy develops sore throat of 4 days duration. On examination, yellow grayish patch was seen over both the tonsils and foul smell coming from his mouth. Which of the following non-suppurative complication is of concern?
questions.solution:
• Streptococcal pharyngitis can complicate into acute rheumatic fever as well as acute glomerulonephritis 
  • Streptococcal skin infection in the form of impetigo leads to only acute glomerulonephritis.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 367

questions.text: A 4 years old child presented in emergency with stridor, respiratory difficulty and noisy breathing with drooling of saliva. Emergency X-ray showed thumb sign. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Acute epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening illness in which the epiglottis, the flap of cartilage at the back of the throat, becomes severely inflamed.

Child with acute epiglottitis has a toxic look and presents with high fever, stridor & respiratory difficulty.

On X ray lateral view of neck, inflamed epiglottis looks like a thumb projecting. This is referred to as Thumb sign. 
 


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 368,376

choices.text: Nasal washings for Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) and influenza

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the emergency department at 3 AM. The child presented with a fever and cough. On examination, respiratory rate was 36/min, temperature was 39°C, and saturation on pulse oximetry was 96%. The child has a barking cough and stridor only on crying. Otherwise, the child was hydrated, able to drink and consolable. The next step in management would be:
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of mild croup as the patient has stridor only on crying with normal sPO2.
  • . A single dose of dexamethasone (oral or intramuscular) is typically the first-line treatment for mild croup, even if the symptoms are not severe. It helps reduce airway swelling and improve symptoms.
  •   Single dose of dexamethasone- 015-0.6 mg/kg.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with a painless lump on the right side of the abdomen detected incidentally on bathing by parents. Ultrasound revealed it to be a solid mass. On examination, his right arm and leg were found to be longer. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• The right arm and leg were found to be longer in the child pointing towards hemihypertrophy. 
  • Hemihypertrophy is a known syndromic association (seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with an increased risk of having Wilms Tumor. 
  • Wilms tumor is also known as Nephroblastoma - hence the correct answer is option (2).
  • Wilms tumor is the most common renal malignancy in children, usually presenting between ages 2 to 5 years. It often manifests as a painless abdominal mass and may be discovered incidentally or during a routine examination - similar to the given clinical scenario in the question. 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2681-2684

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate in the neonatal ICU develops seizures. Which of the following would be the next best investigation for the child?
questions.solution:
• Cranial ultrasonography is particularly practical in case of premature neonates in order to assess various features including ventricular size, presence of fluid-filled lesions, and indications of either haemorrhagic or ischaemic damage, in addition to charting how conditions may evolve.
  • Transcranial USG can be done in neonates due to presence of fontanelles. 
  • It is advantageous in this respect as it can be conducted at the bedside, less time consuming and no hazard of radiation exposure. 



Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols 2 nd Edition page no 78

questions.text: In India, neonatal sepsis is most likely to be caused by:
questions.solution:
• In India, unlike the Western/developed world - the most common cause of neonatal sepsis are gram-negative bacilli-like Kleibsella/Acinetobacter/E.Coli etc. 
  • In India - most common cause of neonatal sepsis is Acinetobacter as per AIIMS NICU Protocols. Other textbooks give Kleibsella as the most common cause. In western world - most common cause is GBS(Group B streptococcus)
  • Since the question was asked in AIIMS/INICET - better answer is option 1(Acenitobacter)
#controversial

Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols 3rd Edition page 259.

choices.text: Not able to go up and down stairs at 5 years of age
Not able to say 2 words phrase at 12 months of age

questions.text: All of the following are considered development delay except:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (4) - Not able to say 2 words phrase at 12 months of age

The ability to use two-word phrases develops at 24 months of age. At 12 months, a child is only expected to say one or two single words with meaning, such as “mama” or “dada.” Thus, not being able to form two-word phrases at 12 months is perfectly normal and cannot be considered a delay.

Other options


Option 1 -  Immature pincer grasp normally appears at 9 months. Failure to demonstrate that 12 months would mean fine motor delay.
 
Option 2 - Independent sitting is achieved by 8 months, and if a child is still unable to sit at 10 months, that means gross motor delay.

Option 3 - Children is able to go up and down stairs by 2 years of age. Inability to do so at 5 years indicates a delay in gross motor development. 

 

Reference - Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 44,46,48,49,50

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely in PDA?
questions.solution:
• Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) is a common congenital heart defect where the fetal ductus arteriosus (DA) fails to close shortly after birth, allowing oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to flow between the aorta and the pulmonary artery.
  • This creates a shunt between the two vessels, resulting in increased pulmonary and systemic circulation, eventually resulting in volume overload.
  • Features: Increase in pulmonary flow and systemic flow, Bounding pulses
  • Heart Sounds: The second heart sound is slowly fading and the diastolic murmurs may be present
  • CO2 wash out is not seen in PDA
  • It can lead to necrotizing enterocolitis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 414-416

questions.text: 7-year-old child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome has developed corticosteroid toxicity and posterior subcapsular cataracts and uncontrolled hypertension. Which of the following is the best alternative for the treatment of the patient?
questions.solution:
• In patients with Frequent Relapsing Nephrotic Syndrome - Levamisole is the preferred steroid-sparing agent while MMF is the preferred agent in Steroid dependent Nephrotic syndrome
  • However, a 12-week course of Cyclophosphamide is preferred over Levamisole/MMF in patients with evidence of severe steroid toxicity (like the example given in question - cataracts and uncontrolled hypertension) or having compliance issues. Hence in the above question, option(2) is a better answer as compared to option (3).

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 476-477

choices.text: Growth plate healing is seen on X-ray
Bone specific alkaline phosphate levels become normal

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and is also suffering from congenital Talipes equinovarus (CTEV). The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when:
questions.solution:
• The medical management of rickets, comprising vitamin D and calcium supplements in appropriate doses, must be employed prior to considering surgery, as success consequently relies upon the healing potential of rickets.
  • Corrective osteotomy in rickets should only be done once after radiological healing has taken place[option 2] (i.e growth plate healing is seen on X-ray), otherwise the osteotomy will not unite due to defective mineralization. 

Other options

  • Option 1 (Vitamin D levels normal): Not reliable because vitamin D can normalize biochemically before growth plates fully heal.
  • Option 3 (Bone-specific ALP normal): ALP is a marker of osteoblastic activity but may remain elevated for some time, even after healing has started. It is not used as the deciding factor for surgery.
  • Option 4 (Serum calcium normal): Calcium often normalizes quickly with supplementation, but deformity correction is deferred until radiographic healing is evident.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 112-116

questions.text: An elderly female sustained Colle's fracture in her right hand, which was properly treated and cast was removed. After some weeks, she now complains of pain out of proportion and swelling with stiffness in the wrist with cyanosis discoloration and trophic changes in the fingers. X-ray of the hand revealed complete decalcification. She is most likely suffering from:
questions.solution:
Presence of severe pain out of proportion, stiffness in the wrist with cyanosis and trophic changes in fingers, weeks after injury and treatment with cast suggests a diagnosis of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome Type I (Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy) also known as Sudeck's atrophy. It occurs due to Sympathetic nervous system dysfunction, in this case due to trauma. 
Its features include :-
1. Burning or electric-shock-like pain.
2. Skin tenderness.
3. Allodynia (sensitivity to touch).
4. Decreased range of motion in an affected area.
5. Changes in the skin over an affected area, such as inflammation, discoloration, and increased sweating.
6. Weakness in an affected area.
7. Osteoporosis, which may lead to fractures.
8. Swelling in an affected area.
9. Limited mobility.
10. Aesthetic deformities such as shortening of affected muscles, joint deformity, and clubbing.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 51,52

questions.text: A 24 years old college student while playing hockey injured his right knee. This patient presents after 3 months with instability of knee joint in full extension without instability at 90 degree of flexion. The structure most commonly damaged is:
questions.solution:
• The postero-lateral bundle helps to resist hyperextension, anterior translation and rotation when the knee is in an extended position.
  • The posterolateral part of the ACL is the most commonly injured region of the ACL.
  • The fact that there is no instability at 90 degrees of flexion indicates that the ACL injury is likely limited to the posterolateral part of the ligament.
  • If the knee is hyperextended and internally rotated, the posterior lateral bundle is particularly susceptible to injury.
  • If this bundle is damaged, there is an increased range of motion in hyperextension and anterior translation at the knee joint when extended.
  • Therefore, postero-lateral bundle of anterior cruciate ligament is the most commonly damaged structure in above mentioned situation.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148,149

choices.text: Distal segment is dislocated anteriorly more than posterior
Cubitus valgus more common than cubitus varus during malunion

questions.text: Which of the following is true about supracondylar fracture of humerus?
questions.solution:
• Nerve injury related manifestations are transitory
  • Option 1. Posterior and not anterior dislocation is common for distal fragment in supracondylar humerus fracture
  • Option 2. Malunion causing cubitus varus is more common than valgus. Cubitus varus leads to gunstock deformity.
  • Option 4. Most common nerve injury in supracondylar humerus fracture is median nerve.
  • Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is a common type of elbow injury that occurs in children.
  • Nerve injury is a common complication of supracondylar fractures. The most commonly injured nerve is the median nerve, followed by the radial and ulnar nerves.
  • The nerve injury related manifestations can include numbness, tingling, weakness, and loss of sensation in the hand and fingers. However, these manifestations are usually temporary and resolve within a few weeks to months.


Reference: Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar, 5th Edition Pages 138-141

questions.text: The most serious complication of a pelvic fracture is:
questions.solution:
• Pelvic fractures can cause significant bleeding due to the large blood vessels that run through the pelvis.
  • The most serious complication of a pelvic fracture is hypovolemic shock. Pelvic fracture causes approximately 1L blood loss. 
  • Treatment -Stop the  bleeding, replacing lost blood with fluids, blood and blood products, and stabilizing the patient's condition. Pelvic Binder is recommended in hemodynamically unstable patients  as it reduces pelvic volume and controls bleeding {Contraindicated in open pelvic fractures.}

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 128

questions.text: Shortening of lower limb with adduction and internal rotation is observed in which of the following types of hip dislocation?
questions.solution:
• Posterior dislocation- Flexed, Internally rotated, Adducted
  • Anterior dislocation- Flexed, Externally Rotated, Abducted



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 130

questions.text: In 2 years old child gallows traction is applied. Child is suffering from fracture of:
questions.solution:
• Gallow's traction is used for treatment of fracture shaft of femur, in infants and children <2 years of age.
  • Weight must not be >12 kgs.
  • Both the fractured and the normal femur are placed in skin traction and infant is suspended by these from a special frame.
  • The buttocks should be lifted just off the bed so that the weight of the body provides counter traction and the fracture is reduced.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 143

questions.text: A policemen found a person lying unconscious in right lateral position on the road with superficial injury to the face, bruises on the right arm, and injury to the lateral aspect of right knee. Nerve most probably injured:
questions.solution:
The nerve most likely injured in this case is common peroneal nerve in the region of fibular neck where it lies in close proximity to skin and subcutaneous tissue. 


Common peroneal nerve- 
 
  • origin: one of two terminal branches of the sciatic nerve
  • course: diverges laterally to enter the lateral compartment of the leg
  • terminal branches
    • deep peroneal nerve
    • superficial peroneal nerve
  • motor supply: short head biceps femoris
  • sensory supply: cutaneous innervation of posterolateral leg

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 46

questions.text: A patient with conjunctival infection, which led to corneal perforation, was positive for Gram-negative coccoid appearance on Gram stain. Further investigation showed small translucent colonies, which is oxidase positive. What could be the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Infection with Gram negative diplococci forming small translucent colonies, which is oxidase positive is indicative of Neisseria gonorrhea.
  • Most common cause of Acute purulent/ Hyperacute conjunctivitis is N. gonorrhoeae > N. meningitidis
  • Moraxella is also a gram negative, oxidase positive cocci but Moraxella catarrhalis occur more commonly in young children and may occur in institutional epidemics. Moraxella axenfield is the causative organism of Angular conjunctivitis.
  • Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter are gram negative bacilli.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: Premature baby weighing 1000 gms or less is most likely to suffer from:
questions.solution:
Premature infants who are exposed to high levels of oxygen within the first ten days of life are at risk of developing bilateral proliferative retinopathy.

This is caused by vasoconstriction of immature vessels due to the high levels of oxygen, leading to hypoxia of retina causing neovascularization and  formation of fibrous tissue. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 537.

questions.text: An elderly female presented with recurrent swelling of the upper eyelid. Histopathological evaluation revealed it to be a chalazion. What would be the histopathological finding?
questions.solution:
• Chalazion is also known as meibomian or tarsal cyst.
  • It is a chronic, sterile, lipogranulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland containing sebaceous secretion. Occurs due to a chronic blockage of meibomian gland orifice and stagnation of sebaceous secretions.
  • HPE shows clear circular empty spaces presumably represent lipids that have dissolved in the organic solvents during processing.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1301.

questions.text: Diffuse mottling of retina with focal areas of increased and decreased pigmentation between posterior pole and equator (Salt and pepper retinopathy) is observed in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Resolving retinal detachment is not related to salt and pepper retinopathy and is instead a consequence of a traumatic ocular event.
 
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy is an inherited condition and usually affects the peripheral retina.
  • It is characterized by diffuse mottling of the retina with focal areas of increased and decreased pigmentation between the posterior pole and the equator.
  • The condition is usually benign and does not progress to any underlying retinal pathology.
Causes of Salt and Pepper retinopathy are:
  1. Congenital Rubella syndrome
  2. Congenital Syphilis syndrome
  3. Leber's amaurosis
  4. Fundus Flavimaculatus (Stargardt's disease)
  5. Thioridazine/Phenothiazine toxicity
  6. Atypical retinitis pigmentosa

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 490, 709, 950.

questions.text: The risk of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is increased in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is a medical condition that occurs when the retina gets separated from the back wall of the eye. This damages the blood vessels and nerve cells in the eye, leading to vision loss. The causes of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment include trauma to the eye, a tear or hole in the retina, lattice degeneration and age-related changes in the vitreous humor that causes the retina to pull away from the back wall of the eye.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 647, 648.

questions.text: Most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma:
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is a common and serious congenital intraocular tumor of childhood occurring in 1 in 15,000-20,000 live births.

It is usually detected between 1-2 years of age and can be bilateral in 25-30% of cases. 90% of the cases are sporadic, while 10% are familial.

Most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma is Leukocoria and strabismus.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.

questions.text: Ocriplasmin is a recombinant protease and it is used to treat:
questions.solution:
Ocriplasmin is a recombinant protease with activity against fibronectin and laminin components of the vitreoretinal interface.

It is used for treatment of symptomatic vitreomacular adhesions.

It works by dissolving the proteins that link the vitreous to the macula, resulting in posterior detachment of the vitreous from the retina.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 613, 614.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not true of acute conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Cornea is NOT infiltrated with conjunctivitis.
  • These infections normally are self-limiting, lasting 7–10 days, antibiotic therapy usually speeds the resolution and lessens the severity of the disease.
  • Topical Antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment in acute bacterial conjunctivitis, not the viral conjunctivitis (Option 3).
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic with good Gram-positive coverage, such as a third- or fourth-generation fluoroquinolone, 10% sodium sulfacetamide, or trimethoprim-polymyxin, may be used for 7–10 days
  • Vision and pupils remain unaffected (Option 1 and 4).
  • So, the better answer will be Option 2.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

choices.text: More common in males as compared to females
Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment

questions.text: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
 
  • Degenerative myopia, characterized by severe nearsightedness and progressive elongation of the eyeball, increases the risk of retinal detachment.
  • The stretching and thinning of the retina in degenerative myopia can lead to retinal tears or breaks, which may progress to retinal detachment if left untreated.

Other options:
  • Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia.
  • It is more common in females as compared to males.
  • Optic disc swelling or Pseudopapillitis is a feature of Hypermetropia, NOT Myopia.


Reference: Parson’s diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 64.

questions.text: Which of the following does not show calcification?
questions.solution:
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a congenital condition characterized by the failure of regression of the primary vitreous during fetal development. It is typically associated with a fibrovascular stalk extending from the optic disc to the lens. While PHPV can present with various ocular abnormalities, calcification is not a typical feature of this condition.

On the other hand, the other options mentioned can show calcification:

  1. Optic nerve Drusen: Optic nerve Drusen refers to calcified deposits that can accumulate within the optic nerve head. These calcified deposits can be visualized on fundus examination.

  2. Choroid osteoma: Choroid osteoma is a rare benign tumor of the choroid layer in the eye. It is characterized by the presence of mature bone tissue. Calcification is a prominent feature of choroid osteoma.

  3. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina. It can show calcification within the tumor mass, which can be observed in imaging studies such as computed tomography (CT) or ultrasound.

Therefore, among the given options, option 1 (Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous) is the correct answer as it does not typically show calcification


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 435, 586, 592, 593.
Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.

choices.text: Viral nucleic acid detection from the intraocular fluid
Viral antibody detection in blood by ELISA

questions.text: Most rapid and accurate method to diagnose CMV retinitis:
questions.solution:
Isolation of CMV or detection of its DNA in appropriate clinical specimens is the preferred approach rapid approach for diagnosis of CMV retinitis.
 
  • PCR of ocular fluid offers the highest utility when laboratory confirmation is necessary. Both aqueous and vitreous samples are adequate substrates for PCR.
  • CMV retinitis is typically diagnosed through a comprehensive eye examination conducted by an ophthalmologist.
  • The ophthalmologist will look for telltale signs of retinitis, such as yellow-white patches, retinal hemorrhages, "bull's-eye" lesions, cotton-wool spots, intraretinal exudates, and flame-shaped hemorrhages. 
     
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 704.

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male presents with persistent ear discharge with fever and headache. He complained of pain out of proportion. On examination, granulations and tenderness are observed on the floor of the external auditory canal along with facial nerve palsy. He is not responding to antibiotics. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Malignant otitis externa (MOE) is a severe infection of the external auditory canal and surrounding structures. It is caused by organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus spp, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus aureus, and Aspergillus species. Symptoms include severe ear pain, otorrhea (ear drainage), redness and tender area around the ear, hearing loss, and general malaise. Chronic cases can lead to facial nerve palsy, cranial nerve deficits, as well as osteomyelitis (bone infection). Diagnosis is usually made with imaging tests, such as computed tomography scan and magnetic resonance imaging, IOC- Tc 99m scan and Prognostic IOC- Gallium 67 scan. Treatment usually consists of antibiotics and topical medications, but surgery may be necessary in severe cases.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 55

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with persistent fullness of left ear for 3 months and hearing loss. On examination, there is fluid behind the tympanic membrane. Impedance audiometry shows a type B audiogram. The next step for the management of the patient would be:
questions.solution:
Endoscopic examination is recommended for any nasopharyngeal pathology in a 58-year-old male who presents with persistent fullness of the left ear for 3 months and hearing loss with fluid behind the tympanic membrane, and impedance audiometry showing a type B audiogram.It is to be done before myringotomy, because Nasopharyngeal CA(which is common in this age group) needs to be ruled out before anything else. It can identify any underlying causes of the fluid build-up and hearing loss, such as a tumor, inflammatory process or obstruction of the eustachian tube. The use of endoscopy allows for visual inspection of the nasopharynx and tympanic membranes, as well as the opportunity to take biopsies of any abnormalities in order to make a more accurate diagnosis.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 27

choices.text: A 40 years old male with bilateral profound hearing loss
A 6 years old male with bilateral hearing loss
A 7 years old male with bilateral microtia, canal atresia and congenital hearing loss
A 50 years old male with bilateral acoustic neuroma, planned for surgery

questions.text: Bone anchored hearing aid (BAHA) can be used in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Baha is a type of bone anchored hearing system. Some of the main features and indications of Baha include:

1.When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
- Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment
-Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment
- Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid

2..Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated

3.Single sided hearing loss

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 137

questions.text: Who among the following has contributed to the development of neuro-otology and is considered as the father of 'neuro-otology'?
questions.solution:
William F. House considered as 'Father of Neuro-otology' because of his pioneering development approaches for the removal of acoustic tumors and the management of patients with disabling vertigo.

Reference:https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&url=https%3A%2F%2Fjamanetwork.com%2Fjournals%2Fjamaotolaryngology%2Ffullarticle%2F1655075&psig=AOvVaw183fftXAqgVpwwo0tz88mX&ust=1725450852512000&source=images&cd=vfe&opi=89978449&ved=0CAYQrpoMahcKEwjolO2p26aIAxUAAAAAHQAAAAAQBA

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with left ear discharge and mild ear pain for the past 7 years. There is no history of deafness. On examination, the tympanic membrane is intact and discharge is seen coming from the posterior superior wall. The left ear canal and tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic otitis externa is a chronic infection/inflammation of the skin lining the external ear canal, often caused by repeated local irritation, insertion of foreign objects, or rare chronic infections such as syphilis, tuberculosis, and leprosy. Symptoms include itching, mild pain, asteatosis, thickening of the skin lining of the external canal, and sometimes mucopurulent otorrhea. Treatment includes use of acetic acid ear drops to reduce the pH of the skin and, in extreme cases, surgery such as a canaloplasty to widen the external canal and grafting of the removed skin.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 54

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Bell's palsy except:
questions.solution:
Immediate nerve decompression is not required in Bell's palsy, initially steroids are given and recovery occurs in 85-90% cases. Nerve decompression relieves pressure on the nerve fibers and improves the microcirculation of nerve, done in non-responding cases. Rest all statements are true. 



Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 104

questions.text: A girl for chronic ear discharge, pain on ocular movements and vertigo underwent mastoidectomy. There was no relief post-operatively and continuous purulent ear discharge was seen. Patient also had sensorineural hearing loss. The most probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Petrsoitis is a rare complication of suppurative otitis media affecting both acute and chronic forms. Acute petrositis is marked by extension of mastoiditis into the petrous apex while chronic petrositis usually occurs due to mucosal or cholesteatomatous CSOM and does not require pneumatization of the petrous apex. Classic features include otorrhea with retroorbital pain and lateral rectus palsy (Gradenigo syndrome). Antibiotics and surgical drainage of the petrous apex are recommended for management.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 88

questions.text: A young 8 years old boy with multiple, small, pin point, shiny, papular lesions on dorsal aspect of hand, forearms and his penis also. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Lichen nitidus is a rare skin disorder that is characterized by small, pinhead-sized, shiny, flat-topped papules.
  • These papules often form clusters, which can range in size from a few millimeters to up to a centimeter. They usually appear on the trunk, upper arms, neck, and face, and may be more common in children and adolescents.
  • The color of the papules can vary from yellow-brown, to pink or white. Lichen nitidus is asymptomatic and does not cause itching or irritation.
  • The diagnosis of Lichen nitidus is based on the appearance of the papules. A skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although topical steroids may be used to reduce any inflammation. Long-term prognosis for Lichen nitidus is excellent, as it is considered a harmless condition.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base along the T3 dermatome on the trunk. Which of the following etiological agent is most likely to be implicated?
questions.solution:
• Varicella zoster or shingles is a condition characterized by painful, unilateral vesicular eruptions that occur in a single dermatome, usually on the T3 to L3 area.
  • The prodromal phase of segmental pain preceding the eruption typically starts 1-4 days before its appearance.
  • Edema and erythema are quickly followed by the tuft of vesicles. In some cases, the mucous membranes within the dermatome may also be involved
  • Herpes simplex virus typically causes painful vesicular lesions on the lips or genital area, but it does not follow a dermatomal distribution.
  • Human papilloma virus  causes warts, which are typically painless and do not follow a dermatomal distribution.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.27

questions.text: All of the following drugs can lead to SLE like reaction except?
questions.solution:
• Drugs causing SLE can be remembered by the mnemonic-SHIP
  • S-Sulphonamides H-Hydralazine I-Isoniazid P-Procainamide 
  • They are associated with anti-histone antibodies with equal incidence in males and females and absent renal involvement.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.19

questions.text: A 60 years old man presented with itchy tense blisters on normal looking skin and urticarial rash. Investigation done for the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Features are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid and diagnosis can be done by DIF.  DIF can be used to detect antibodies to different components of the skin, such as the basement membrane zone or desmoglein.
  • These antibodies are present in the majority of individuals with pemphigoid and can be detected by fluorescent staining techniques.
  • Additionally, DIF can also be used to distinguish between other autoimmune skin diseases such as epidermolysis bullosa acquisita  or lichen planus, which may have similar clinical features to pemphigoid.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of the scalp, multiple discharging sinuses, easily pluckable hairs, and lymph nodes enlarged in the occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
• The given features (painful boggy swelling of the scalp, multiple discharging sinuses, easily pluckable hairs) are consistent with that of Kerion or Tinea Capitis.
  • Tinea capitis(scalp ringworm) is a fungal infection of the scalp and hair. It appears as patches of scaling, broken hair, and inflammation or bald spots on the scalp.
  • The most common symptom is itching, but the affected area may also be tender. The diagnosis of tinea capitis is usually based on a physical inspection of the infected area.
  • Confirmation can be achieved using laboratory testing, such as fungal culture on KOH wet mount, direct tissue examination, and Wood's lamp examination.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.39

questions.text: The Ridley-Joplin classification for leprosy is based on which parameters?
questions.solution:
The Ridley-Jopling classification for leprosy is a system designed in 1967 to classify the type of leprosy a person is affected with. The classification takes into account the degree to which patients have been affected by the disease by Clinical, bacteriological and immunological parameters and assigns them one of five stages of severity: 1. Tuberculoid Leprosy: This is the least severe type of leprosy. It affects few areas of skin or nerves, and in some cases can remain stable after treatment. 2. Mid-Range Leprosy: Symptoms may include discolored skin patches, known as macules, and some nerve damage. 3. Borderline Leprosy: Symptoms may include uneven skin patches, patches with several colors, and greater nerve damage, but still no physical deformities. 4. Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy: Symptoms may include large patches with multiple colors, significant nerve damage and physical deformities, such as clubbed fingers. 5. Lepromatous Leprosy: This is the most severe type of leprosy. Symptoms include widespread skin lesions, gross deformities, and general deterioration of health. The Ridley-Jopling classification is based on the appearances of skin lesions, deformities, as well as the degree of body reactions to antigenic and bacterial tests.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.3,28.12

questions.text: Suxamethonium is available as a clear, colourless aqueous solution. The shelf-life of suxamethonium is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 2 years
 
  • Succinylcholine chloride (Sch) is a potent and rapid-acting muscle relaxant. It is a dicholine ester of acetylcholine and was first used clinically by Bovet.
  • It is a clear, colorless, aqueous solution with a pH of 3.0-5.0 and has a shelf life of two years when stored at 4°C. Its action is potentiated by opioid and nitrous oxide anesthesia.
  • At a dose of 1-2 mg/kg, it produces a characteristic effect of sustained partial depolarization of muscle end plate by opening sodium channels and initially producing twitching and fasciculations followed by flaccid paralysis. Its rapid onset of action is mainly due to its low lipid solubility.
  • Succinylcholine has a shelf life of around 18 months, generally stored at 20-40 C and can be stored upto 2 years.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

choices.text: Always occur irrespective of the type of anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hypothermia during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Prevented by giving warm fluids
 
  • Mild hypothermia is an extremely common side effect of anesthesia and surgery.
  • It is caused mainly by skin radiation and convection (sometimes by conduction), and can have negative consequences on patient health, such as postoperative events and slower recovery times.
  • Drug metabolism is also slowed down significantly by hypothermia. 
  • Administering warm fluids can help reduce heat loss and the associated health risks. Other options are non specific.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1666, 1667.
Díaz, Marcos, and Daniel E Becker. “Thermoregulation: physiological and clinical considerations during sedation and general anesthesia.” Anesthesia progress vol. 57,1 (2010): 25-32; quiz 33-4. doi:10.2344/0003-3006-57.1.25

questions.text: A woman is posted for elective cholecystectomy. Her preoperative clinical evaluation and airways assessment was normal. In the operating room, she was attached to the monitors and an antibiotic was administered to her. Suddenly she became pulseless and unresponsive. What should be the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Start chest compression
 
  • A patient, who suddenly becomes pulseless and unresponsive during giving drugs, in that start chest compression first because Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is the most effective way to keep oxygen-rich blood flowing throughout the body.
  • Starting chest compressions will pump blood to vital organs and keep them functioning until the patient can be revived.
  • Chest compressions will reduce the chances of brain damage or death due to lack of oxygen if the patient is not breathing and has no pulse.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2261.
Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: Lithium potentiates the action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. How many days before administration of the muscle relaxant should lithium be stopped?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2 days
 
  • Lithium tends to potentiate the action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants given during surgery.
  • In addition, during the perioperative period - dehydration, use of diuretics, and hyponatremia can occur which can also exacerbate the toxicity of lithium. 
  • Lithium has a half-life of 18-24 hours - hence it's advised to stop it 48-72 hours prior to surgery or the use of any non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. 
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 474.

questions.text: A patient posted for surgery has raised intracranial tension. Which of the following anesthetics would be preferred in him?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Sevoflurane> Isoflurane 
 
  • The changes in cerebral blood volume, CSF dynamics, and arterial CO2 tension brought about by volatile anesthetics lead to an overall effect on ICP.
  • By contrast, all the volatile anesthetics can be, depending on physiologic and pharmacologic circumstances, dose-dependent cerebral vasodilators. The order of vasodilating potency is approximately halothane → enflurane → desflurane → isoflurane → sevoflurane
  • Sevoflurane causes least vasodilation, hence it causes least increase in ICP.
  • The CBF differences among desflurane, isoflurane, and sevoflurane are unlikely to be clinically significant
  • Sevoflurane appears to be the best for patients where intracranial compliance is low. 
  • This is because Sevoflurane has the least effect on cerebral blood flow (CBF) and cerebral metabolic rate (CMR) among the four anesthetics mentioned in the options
  • Therefore, Anesthetic agent of Choice for Neurosurgery is Sevoflurane> Isoflurane.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1872.

questions.text: Vasopressor of choice in anesthesia for a patient of aortic stenosis, who develops hypotension during surgery, is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Phenylephrine
  • Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice (causes vasoconstriction) to restore coronary perfusion in patients with severe aortic stenosis when under general anesthesia because of its ability to acutely increase systolic and diastolic arterial pressure.
  • It is a alpha1 agonist so its ability to increase central vascular resistance without significantly altering heart rate helps to reduce the risk of aortic valve obstruction. Its ability to maintain cyclical systemic blood pressure makes it a suitable vasopressor for the maintenance of coronary perfusion in such patients.
  • However, second best answer can be Ephedrine


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1732, 1740, 1859.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetic agent is contraindicated in epileptic patients posted for general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Ketamine
 
  • Ketamine should be avoided in patients who have a history of seizures since it raises ICP and produces delirium and hallucinations.
  • Ketamine is a sympathomimetic drugs as it inhibits the metabolism of catecholamines and can, therefore trigger seizures.
  • Ketamine increases cerebral metabolism, CBF, and ICP. Because of its excitatory CNS effects, which can be detected by generalized EEG development of theta wave activity and by petit mal seizure-like activity in the hippocampus
  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine and is seen in 30-40% of the people.
  • Auditory hallucinations are more common than visual hallucinations.


Other options: 
  • Option 1: Propofol may suppress seizure activity via GABA agonism, inhibition of NMDA receptors, and modulation of slow calcium ion channels. Propofol has neuroprotective action.
  • Option 2 & 4: Thiopentone and Midazolam has anti-epileptic property as they act via the GABA-A receptors to release GABA. Thiopentone has anticonvulsant action due to its phenyl group. Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used in treatment of seizures



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 641, 642, 656, 663.

choices.text: Pneumonia affecting medial zone of right middle lobe
Pneumonia affecting superior zone of right lower lobe
Pneumonia of anterior zone of right middle lobe

questions.text: A patient presents with cough and fever. On X-ray examination, a homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins is seen. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The cardiac silhouette on the right side of the lung with an ill-defined lateral border is indicative of pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe.
  • Cardiac silhouettes are be beneficial in identifying the location of pulmonary abnormalities, since all parts of the cardiac silhouette, including the heart border, ascending and descending aorta, aortic knob, and hemidiaphragm, are located adjacent to a certain area of the lung.


Image showing Pneumonia of Medial part of RML



Reference: Grainger & Alison's Diagnostic Radiology,7th edition, Page no 34.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1010.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen on ultrasound in acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Increased cortical vascularity.
 
  • An examination of the renal parenchyma with an ultrasound could reveal small Ultrasound carries low sensitivity to detect changes of acute pyelonephritis.
  • Majority of the patients having 'normal' scans.
  • Ultrasound evident abnormalities are detected in only ~25% of cases which includes 
  • Abnormal echogenicity of renal parenchyma 
    • Focal/segmental hypoechoic areas due to edema or hyperechoic areas due to hemorrhage
  • Particulate free floating echoes/debris in the collecting system
  • Reduced areas of cortical vascularity on power Doppler 
  • Areas of air foci in case of emphysematous pyelonephritis. 
  • Utilized predominantly in assessing for local complications and guiding its management such as:
    • Hydronephrosis
    • Renal abscess formation
    • Renal infarction
    • Perinephric collections 

Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 767, 795.
Gaillard F, Walizai T, Niknejad M, et al. Acute pyelonephritis. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://radiopaedia.org/articles/9953

questions.text: A 70 years old female is on treatment with Alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis. Now she complains of pain in right thigh. What is the next best  investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
2. X-ray

  • Thigh pain in a patient on long-term bisphosphonate therapy (e.g., Alendronate) raises concern for an atypical femoral fracture (AFF), which is a known rare complication of prolonged bisphosphonate use.
  • X-ray is the first-line investigation to evaluate for an atypical femoral fracture. It may show a transverse fracture or signs of a stress reaction (e.g., cortical thickening) in the femoral diaphysis, even before a complete fracture develops.

Other options:
 
  1. DEXA scan: Measures bone density but does not help in identifying fractures or stress reactions, so it is not relevant for diagnosing the source of pain.
  2. Serum vitamin D levels: Important for assessing bone health but not directly related to evaluating the cause of thigh pain.
  3. Serum alkaline phosphatase levels: Can indicate increased bone turnover in certain conditions but is not specific for diagnosing an atypical femoral fracture.
DEXA scans can measure tiny reductions in bone density. This makes it possible to diagnose osteoporosis in its early stages but it is not used as an investigation to diagnose femur fracture.

Category Bone mass (BMD derived from DEXA measurement)
  • Normal- Spinal or hip BMD within 1.0 SD below the young adult female reference mean (T-score ≥ -1.0)
  • Low bone mass (osteopenia)- Spinal or hip BMD between 1.0 and 2.5 SDs below the young adult female reference mean (T-score<-1.0 and >-2.5)
  • Osteoporosis- Spinal or hip BMD ≥ 2.5 SDs below the young adult female reference mean (T-score ≤ -2.5)
  • Severe/established osteoporosis BMD ≥ 2.5 SDs below the young adult female reference mean and the presence of one or more fragility fractures.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 89, 90.

questions.text: In a child of Rett syndrome, all of the following are seen except:
questions.solution:
• Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused due to MECP2 gene mutation that begins soon after birth and manifests around 1-2 years of age.
  • Its almost exclusively seen in females.
  • It is characterized by a neurodevelopmental regression(slowing of cognitive, social, and physical development) sudden behavior changes, and repetitive hand movements/autistic behavior.
  • Other features include seizures, slowed head growth causing microcephaly (NOT Macrocephaly as mentioned in option 1), difficulties with motor coordination, and scoliosis.
  • Trofinetide(Tripeptide - (Gly - Pro - Glu) - analog of the neuropeptide (1-3) IGF-1) is a new drug used for its treatment.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3192,3193

questions.text: A known alcoholic is brought to the emergency department by his wife. The person has not consumed alcohol for the past two days due to religious reasons. The person complained of nausea, vomiting and dizziness. On the second day, he developed seizures, that progressed to generalized tonic clonic seizures (GTCs). Which of the following would be the best medication to manage the seizures of the patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diazepam
 
  • Antidepressant medications with long-acting abilities, like chlordiazepoxide and diazepam, and those with shorter-acting abilities, such as lorazepam, can be used to safely treat mild to moderate (without major complications) cases of alcohol withdrawal.
  • Chlordiazepoxide is the preferred drug of choice for treating alcohol withdrawal syndrome over diazepam.
* BZDs safe in liver dysfunction: - 
LOve The liver- Lorazepam, Oxazepam, Temazepam 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 494.

questions.text: Anti-craving drug given in alcohol dependence is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Acamprosate
 
  • Acamprosate, marketed under the brand name Campral, is an Anti craving drug used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.
  • It works by blocking the neurochemical pathways that lead to cravings for alcohol and restoring the balance of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glutamate.
  • It has been shown to be effective in reducing cravings and increasing abstinence from alcohol. Acamprosate has also been found to reduce relapse rates in individuals with a history of heavy drinking.
  • It is thought to be most successful when used in combination with counseling and other treatments for alcohol addiction.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: According to Wechsler intelligence scale scoring, average IQ of a normal child is:
questions.solution:
According to Wechsler intelligence scale scoring, average IQ of a normal child is 100 with a standard deviation of 15, thus best answer being 90.
  • The Wechsler Intelligence Scales are a series of assessments designed to measure an individual’s cognitive abilities.
  • These assessments help clinicians assess an individual’s cognitive functioning and provide an understanding of an individual’s intellectual strengths and weaknesses. The tests are composed of both verbal and performance tasks, which are all scored separately.
  • The scores are calculated using individual scores, developmental scores, and composite scores, enabling clinicians to assess an individual’s abilities within a range of categories.
  • These categories include verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, and processing speed.
  • The scores are used to compare the individual’s cognitive abilities in comparison to other individuals of similar ages and genders.
  • The Wechsler Intelligence Scales are a standardized measure of intelligence, providing a reliable and valid assessment, which helps clinicians determine cognitive strengths and weaknesses and devise effective treatment plans for individuals with learning or intellectual disabilities.


Reference- https://geniustests.com/about-wechsler/wechsler-intelligence-scale

questions.text: In Piaget's theory of cognitive development 'out of sight' out of mind' and 'here and now' is seen in the stage of:
questions.solution:
In Piaget's theory of cognitive development, the “out of sight, out of mind” and “here and now” concepts are seen in the Sensory-motor stage. In this stage, which occurs from birth to around two years of age, infants focus primarily on what they can see and feel right now in their surroundings.

They develop a preference for familiar objects and people, and do not make associations between objects that are not present. For example, an infant may be comforted by its mother’s touch and get upset when she is not around, instead of forming an understanding that its mother is coming back soon.

This reflects the 'here and now' concept, where objects and people that cannot be seen or touched have little relevance or understanding. It also reflects the 'out of sight, out of mind' concept, where any objects that are not in an infant's immediate environment are forgotten or ignored.

Other options
 

  • Preoperational stage (2–7 years): Egocentric thinking, symbolic play, but still no logical reasoning.

  • Concrete operational stage (7–11 years): Begins logical thought about concrete things, understands conservation.

  • Formal operational stage (11+ years): Abstract thinking, hypothesis testing, future planning.




Reference- https://www.webmd.com/children/piaget-stages-of-development

questions.text: A study comparing the behavioral and developmental changes in a normal brain with a damaged brain is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Neuropsychology
 
  • Clinical neuropsychology is the application of neuropsychological knowledge to the assessment, management, rehabilitation of the people who have suffered illness or injury(particularly to the brain), which has caused neurocognitive problems.
  • Thus, comparing the behavioral and developmental changes in a normal brain with a damaged brain.
  • Neurodevelopmental psychology  is a subfield of psychology that focuses on the study of how the brain and nervous system develop over time, particularly during childhood.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 236.

questions.text: The self awareness regarding the disease in a psychiatric patient in the mental status examination is called:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Insight
 
  • Insight is an important element of a mental status examination and refers to an individual’s awareness and understanding of their mental illness.
  • Having insight regarding one's illness means that a patient is aware of their disorder and can accurately identify the symptoms that they are experiencing. It implies a level of awareness and understanding of their illness, as well as the potential effects of their disorder on their daily functioning.
  • Insight can be evaluated through direct questioning and observations of the individual's behavior. Without insight, individuals may be unaware of their symptoms and the need for treatment, making proper diagnosis and care more difficult.
Other options:
  • Orientation: State of awareness of oneself and one's surroundings in terms of time, place, and person. (Option 2)
  • Judgment: Mental act of comparing or evaluating choices within the framework of a given set of values for the purpose of electing a course of action. (Option 3)
  • Rapport: a relationship characterized by agreement, mutual understanding, or empathy that makes communication possible or easy (Option 4)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1413, 1415.
